text:
In the Name of Allah, the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate

Indeed, all praise is due to Allah; we praise Him, seek His help, seek His forgiveness, and repent to Him. And we seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our own souls and from our misdeeds. Whomever Allah guides, none can mislead; and whomever He leaves astray, none can guide. And I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, without partner; and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger.

{O you who believe! Fear Allah as He should be feared, and do not die except as Muslims} (1)

{O mankind! Fear your Lord who created you from a single soul, and created from it its mate, and dispersed from them many men and women; and fear Allah through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed, Allah is ever watching over you} (2)

{O you who believe! Fear Allah and speak words of appropriate justice. He will rectify your deeds for you and forgive you your sins; and whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger has certainly attained a great triumph} (3)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: As for what follows, I had printed at the end of the year (1377) AH a treatise titled "Warning the Worshipper against Taking Graves as Mosques." My personal copy of this edition was with me throughout this period; whenever I came across an additional benefit suitable for its topic, I would annotate it, hoping to include it when reprinting it expanded and revised. Thus, I accumulated many important additions. When the noble professor Zuhair Al-Shawish, owner of Al-Maktab Al-Islami, asked me to present it to him to reprint it, I looked for it but did not find it. When I despaired of finding it, I sent him another copy I borrowed from some of my friends to be printed as is, based on the rule: "What cannot be fully attained should not be fully abandoned." While my brother Professor Zuhair Al-Shawish was preparing to print it, I found it by the grace and generosity of Allah Almighty. I hastened to send it to him after refining it and preparing it for the second edition. Since the writing of the mentioned treatise had special circumstances and specific conditions at that time, wisdom required its style to be contrary to calm research and solid reasoning. That is because it was a response to people who did not like our call to the Book and the Sunnah according to the methodology of the righteous predecessors (Salaf) and the plan of the four Imams and others who followed them in goodness. So they initiated writing and responding to us. Would that it had been a calm scientific response; then I would have met them with better than it. But unfortunately, it was not so; rather, it was devoid of any scientific research, filled with insults and abuse, and inventing accusations never heard before. Therefore, we did not see at that time that it was wise to remain silent about them and leave them to spread their treatises among the people without having an author to unveil the ignorance and accusations therein, {so that those who perished [through disbelief] would perish upon evidence and those who lived [in faith] would live upon evidence} (4). Therefore, it was necessary to respond to them by name. Although I did not meet their aggression and fabrication with the like, the treatise, despite its scientific nature, was a direct response to them. It may contain some harshness or severity in style in the opinion of some people who pretend to be displeased with responding to fabricating opponents and wish they were left without being held accountable for their ignorance and accusation of the innocent, imagining that silence about them is tolerance that may fall under the like of the Almighty's saying {And when the ignorant address them [harshly], they say [words of] peace} (5). They forget or pretend to forget that this helps them continue in their misguidance and misleading of others, and Allah Almighty says {And do not cooperate in sin and aggression} (6). And what sin and aggression is greater than accusing a Muslim of what is not in him, rather, contrary to what he is? If some of those pretending what we mentioned were afflicted by aggression less than what afflicted us, they would hasten to respond, and their state would recite:

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Let no one act ignorantly against us, lest we act more ignorantly than the ignorant. I say despite that: I see that reprinting the treatise in its previous form has no significant benefit. Therefore, it was necessary to delete some comments and modify a few phrases to refine its style and suit its new edition without diminishing its scientific value and important research. I had mentioned in the introduction to the first edition that the subject of the treatise is confined to two very important matters: First: The ruling on building mosques over graves. Second: The ruling on praying in these mosques. I preferred researching them because some people delved into them without knowledge and said what no scholar before them had said, especially since most people have absolutely no knowledge about it. They are heedless of it, oblivious, and ignorant of the truth. They are supported in this by the silence of scholars about them - except whom Allah wills, and how few they are - out of fear of the common people or flattering them to preserve their status in their hearts, forgetting the saying of Allah Blessed and Exalted {Indeed, those who conceal what We sent down of clear proofs and guidance after We made it clear for the people in the Scripture - those are cursed by Allah and cursed by those who curse} (7) and his saying, peace be upon him: "Whoever conceals knowledge, Allah will bridle him on the Day of Resurrection with a bridle of fire." (8) The result of this silence and that ignorance was that many people ended up committing what Allah Almighty forbade and cursed its doer, as will be explained. Would that the matter stopped at this limit, but some of them began to draw closer to Allah Blessed and Exalted by that. You see many lovers of goodness and construction among them spending huge amounts of money to establish a mosque for Allah, but he prepares a grave in it recommending that he be buried in it after his death. The latest example I know of this, and may it be the last, God willing, is this mosque at the head of Baghdad Street from the western side in Damascus, known as "Ba'ira Mosque," and his grave is in it. We were informed that the Awqaf (Endowments) objected to his burial at first, then we do not know the real reasons that prevented them from what they wanted, and "Ba'ira" was buried in his mosque, rather in its Qibla. Indeed to Allah we belong and indeed to Him we return, and He is the Helper to get rid of these evils and their likes.

8. - Hasan Hadith narrated by Ibn Hibban in his Sahih number (296) and Al-Hakim (1 / 102) and he authenticated it and Al-Dhahabi agreed.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: A few days ago, one of the Shafi'i Muftis passed away, and his relatives wanted to bury him in one of the old mosques east of Damascus. The Awqaf also objected to that, so he was not buried there. We thank the Awqaf for these good stances and its keenness to prevent burial in mosques, hoping from Allah Blessed and Exalted that the motive for this prevention is the pleasure of Allah Almighty and following His Sharia, not other political or social considerations, etc., and that this be a good beginning from it in the way of purifying mosques from the innovations and evils crowded in them, especially since the Minister of Awqaf, his eminence Sheikh Al-Baqouri, has noble stances in fighting many of these evils, especially building mosques over graves, and he has useful words on this subject that will be quoted in the appropriate place, God willing. It is truly regrettable for every believer that many mosques in Syria and elsewhere are not free from the presence of a grave or more in them, as if Allah Blessed and Exalted commanded that and did not curse its doer. How well the Awqaf would do if it tried with its wisdom to purify these mosques from them. I do not doubt that it is not wise to surprise public opinion with that; rather, it must be informed first of all that the grave and the mosque do not gather in the religion of Islam, as some prominent scholars said as will come, and that their gathering together contradicts the sincerity of Tawhid and worship to Allah Blessed and Exalted, this sincerity for the realization of which mosques are built, as the Almighty said {And [He revealed] that the masjids are for Allah, so do not invoke with Allah anyone} (9). (9) - Surah Al-Jinn Verse 18

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: I believe that clarifying this is an inescapable duty, and perhaps I have succeeded in doing so in this treatise. I have collected in it the Mutawatir (mass transmitted) hadiths prohibiting that and followed them by mentioning the Madhhabs (schools of thought) of scholars and their considered opinions that indicate that, and testify at the same time that the Imams, may Allah be pleased with them, were most keen on following the Sunnah and inviting people to follow it and warning against opposing it. But Allah the Great spoke the truth saying: {But there came after them successors who neglected prayer and pursued desires; so they are going to meet evil} (10). These are the chapters of the treatise: Chapter One: On the hadiths prohibiting taking graves as mosques. Chapter Two: On the meaning of taking graves as mosques. Chapter Three: On taking graves as mosques being among the major sins. Chapter Four: Doubts and their answers. Chapter Five: On the wisdom of prohibiting building mosques over graves. Chapter Six: On the dislike of praying in mosques built over graves. Chapter Seven: That the previous ruling includes all mosques except the Prophet's Mosque. Within these chapters are other sub-chapters containing important useful benefits, God willing. I have named the treatise: (Warning the Worshipper against Taking Graves as Mosques). That is what I wrote in the introduction to the first edition. I ask Allah Blessed and Exalted to benefit Muslims with this edition more than the previous one, and to accept it from me and all my righteous deeds with good acceptance, and reward the one undertaking its printing with good. Damascus on 23 Jumada Al-Awwal 1392 AH.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 1 - From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said during his illness from which he did not recover: "Allah cursed the Jews and the Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques." She said: "Were it not for that, his grave would have been made prominent (11), but it was feared that it might be taken as a mosque." (12) (11) - Meaning his grave, peace be upon him, would be uncovered and no barrier would be taken over it, and the intent is buried outside his house. So in "Fath Al-Bari". Benefit: This statement of Aisha clearly indicates the reason for which they buried the Prophet, peace be upon him, in his house, which is to block the way for anyone who might build a mosque over him. Thus, it is not permissible in this case to use that as evidence for burying anyone other than him, peace be upon him, in the house. This is supported by the fact that it is contrary to the principle because the Sunnah is burial in cemeteries. Therefore, Ibn Urwah said in "Al-Kawkab Al-Durri" (Vol. 1, Folio 188 / Tafsir 548): "Burial in Muslim cemeteries is more pleasing to Abu Abdullah (meaning Imam Ahmad) than burial in houses because it is less harmful to the living among his heirs, more like the dwellings of the Hereafter, and more conducive to supplication for him and asking for mercy upon him. His companions, the followers, and those after them continued to be buried in the deserts. If it is said: But the Prophet, peace be upon him, was buried in his house and his two companions were buried with him? We say: Aisha said: That was done only so that his grave would not be taken as a mosque. Also, because the Prophet, peace be upon him, used to bury his companions in Baqi', and his action is more worthy than the action of others. His companions only saw fit to single him out with that. And because it was narrated: 'Prophets are buried where they die,' and to protect them from frequent trampling, distinguishing him from others." (2) - Narrated by Al-Bukhari (3 / 156 & 198 & 8 / 114), Muslim (2 / 76), Abu Awana (1 / 399), Ahmad (6 / 80 & 121 & 255), Al-Siraj in his "Musnad" (3 / 48 / 2) from Urwa from her, and Ahmad (6 / 146 & 252) and Al-Baghawi in "Sharh Al-Sunnah" (Vol. 1 p. 415) printed by Al-Maktab Al-Islami from Saeed bin Al-Musayyib from her, and its chain is authentic according to the conditions of the two Sheikhs.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Similar to this saying of Aisha is what was narrated from her father, may Allah be pleased with them both. Ibn Zanjawayh narrated from Umar Mawla Ghufra who said: When they consulted about the burial of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, someone said: We bury him where he used to pray in his place. Abu Bakr said: I seek refuge in Allah that we make him an idol to be worshipped. Others said: We bury him in Baqi' where his brothers from the Muhajirin were buried. Abu Bakr said: We dislike taking the grave of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, out to Baqi' lest people seek refuge with him from the One to whom belongs the right upon him, and Allah's right is above the right of His Messenger, peace be upon him. If we take him out (Original: delay him), we waste Allah's right, and if we protect him (), we protect the grave of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. They said: So what do you see, O Abu Bakr? He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, saying: "Allah has never taken a prophet except that he was buried where his soul was taken." They said: Then you are, by Allah, a pleasing convincing one. Then they drew a line around the bed, then Ali, Al-Abbas, Al-Fadl, and his family carried him, and the people fell to digging where the bed was. (13)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 2 - From Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "May Allah fight the Jews; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques." (14)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 3 - And 4 from Aisha and Ibn Abbas that when death approached the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he began casting a piece of Khamisa (15) of his over his face. When he felt distressed, he uncovered it from his face and said: "The curse of Allah (13) - Ibn Kathir said: It is disconnected (Munqati') from this aspect, for Umar Mawla Ghufra, along with his weakness, did not catch the days of Al-Siddiq. So in (Al-Jami' Al-Kabir) by Al-Suyuti (3 / 147 / 12) (4) - Narrated by Al-Bukhari (2 / 422), Muslim, Abu Awana, Abu Dawud (2 / 71), Ahmad (2 / 284 & 366 & 396 & 453 & 518), Abu Ya'la in his "Musnad" (278 / 1), Al-Siraj, Al-Sahmi in "Tarikh Jurjan" (349), and Ibn Asakir (14 / 367 / 2) from Saeed bin Al-Musayyib from him, and Muslim also from Yazid bin Al-Asamm from him. Abdur-Razzaq narrated it in his "Musannaf" (1 / 406 / 1589) from the first aspect from him but he stopped it (Mawquf). (15) - A garment of Khazz (silk/wool blend) or wool with markings. So in "Al-Nihaya". I say: The intent here is the second because Khazz is silk as is known now, and it is forbidden for men as established in the Sunnah contrary to those who make it lawful among those who give no weight to the Sunnah be upon the Jews; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques." Aisha says: He was warning against what they did. (16) Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: "It is as if he, peace be upon him, knew that he was departing from that illness, so he feared that his grave would be glorified as those before did, so he cursed the Jews and Christians indicating the condemnation of whoever does their deed." I say: Meaning from this Ummah, and in the coming hadith (6) is the explicit prohibition for them from that, so pay attention.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 5 - From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, she said: During the illness of the Prophet, peace be upon him, some of his wives mentioned a church in the land of Abyssinia called Mariyah. Umm Salama and Umm Habiba had been to the land of Abyssinia, so they mentioned its beauty and its images. She said: [So the Prophet, peace be upon him, raised his head] and said: "Those people, if a righteous man among them died, they built a mosque over his grave and painted those images. They are the worst of creatures in the sight of Allah [on the Day of Resurrection]." (17) Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab said in "Fath Al-Bari": (16) - Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1 / 422 & 6 / 386 & 8 / 116), Muslim (2 / 67), Abu Awana (1 / 399), Al-Nasa'i (1 / 115), Al-Darimi (1 / 326), Ahmad (1 / 218 & 6 / 34 & 229 & 275), and Ibn Saad in "Al-Tabaqat" (2 / 258). Abdur-Razzaq narrated it in "Al-Musannaf" (1 / 406 / 1588) from Ibn Abbas alone. (17) Narrated by Al-Bukhari (1 / 416 & 422), Muslim (2 / 66 /), Al-Nasa'i (1 / 115), Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (4 / 140 Indian print), Ahmad (6 / 51 Al-Maktab Al-Islami print), Abu Awana in his "Sahih" (1 / 400-401) and the context is his, Ibn Saad in "Al-Tabaqat" (2 / 241), Al-Siraj in his "Musnad" (48 / 2), Abu Ya'la in "Al-Tabaqat" (Folio 220 / 2), Al-Bayhaqi (4 / 80), and Al-Baghawi (2 / 415-416). This hadith indicates the prohibition of building mosques over the graves of the righteous and painting their images in them as Christians do. There is no doubt that each of them is forbidden on its own; painting images of humans is forbidden, and building graves over mosques on its own is forbidden as indicated by other texts, some of which will be mentioned. He said: The images in the church mentioned by Umm Habiba and Umm Salama were on walls and the like and had no shadow. Painting images in the likeness of prophets and righteous people to seek blessings and intercession through them is forbidden in the religion of Islam and is of the kind of idol worship. It is what the Prophet, peace be upon him, informed that its people are the worst of creatures in the sight of Allah on the Day of Resurrection. Painting images to emulate seeing them or for amusement and entertainment is forbidden and is among the major sins, and its doer is among the most severely punished people on the Day of Resurrection, for he is unjust, imitating the actions of Allah which no one else can do, and He, the Exalted, there is nothing like unto Him neither in His essence nor in His attributes nor in His actions, Glory be to Him and Exalted. Mentioned in "Al-Kawakib Al-Darari" (Vol. 65 / 82 / 2). I say: There is no difference in prohibition between manual photography and mechanical and photographic photography; rather, differentiating between them is rigidity and modern literalism as I explained in my book "Adab Al-Zifaf" (p. 106-116 Second Edition, Al-Maktab Al-Islami print).

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 6 - From Jundub bin Abdullah Al-Bajali that he heard the Prophet, peace be upon him, five days before he died saying: I have had brothers and friends among you, and I clear myself (18) to Allah from having a Khalil (close friend) among you. For Allah Almighty has taken me as a Khalil just as He took Abraham as a Khalil. If I were to take a Khalil from my Ummah, I would have taken Abu Bakr as a Khalil. Verily [those] who were before you [used to] take the graves of their prophets and righteous people as mosques. Verily, do not take graves as mosques, for I forbid you from that. (19)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 7 - From Al-Harith Al-Najrani, he said: I heard the Prophet, peace be upon him, five days before he died saying: Verily, those who were before you used to take the graves of their prophets and righteous people as mosques. Verily, do not take graves as mosques; I forbid you from that. (20) From Usama bin Zaid that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said during his illness in which he died: "Bring my companions to me." So they entered upon him while he was veiled with a Ma'afiri (21) garment. [He uncovered the veil] and said: "Allah cursed the Jews [and the Christians]; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques." (22)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 9 - From Abu Ubaidah bin Al-Jarrah who said: The last thing the Prophet, peace be upon him, spoke was: Expel the Jews of the people of Hijaz and the people of Najran from the Arabian Peninsula, and know that the worst of people are those who took (and in a narration: take) (23) the graves of their prophets as mosques. (24)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 10 - From Zaid bin Thabit that the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Allah cursed (and in a narration: May Allah fight) the Jews; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques." (25)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 24 - () 19 - Narrated by Muslim (2 / 67-68), Abu Awana (1 / 401) and the context is his, and Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (1 / 84 / 2). Ibn Saad narrated it (2 / 240) concisely without mentioning brothers and taking a Khalil. He said: 18 - Meaning I abstain from this and deny it. Al-Khalil is the one solely relied upon. It is said: It is derived from Al-Khalla with Fath on Khaa which is need, and it is said: From Al-Khulla with Damm on Khaa which is the permeation of love in the heart. So he, peace be upon him, denied that his need and devotion be to other than Allah Almighty. "Sharh Muslim" by Al-Nawawi. (20) - Narrated by Ibn Abi Shaybah (Folio 2 / 83 / 2 and Print 2 / 376) and its chain is authentic according to Muslim's conditions. (21) - Garments in Yemen attributed to Ma'afir, a tribe in Yemen. "Nihaya". (22) - Narrated by Al-Tayalisi in his Musnad (2 / 113 of his arrangement), Ahmad (5 / 204), and Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir" (Vol. 1 Folio 22 / 1) and its chain is Hasan with witnesses. Al-Shawkani said in "Nayl Al-Awtar" (2 / 114) "Its chain is Jayyid (good)". Al-Haythami said in "Majma' Al-Zawa'id" (2 / 27) "Its men are trustworthy (Muwaththaqun)". (23) - There is a clear difference between the two narrations. The first narration refers to people who passed, namely the Jews and Christians as in the previous hadiths. The other narration refers to those who follow their path from this Ummah, and it is supported by hadiths (6, 7, 12). (25) Narrated by Ahmad (5 / 184, 186) and its men are trustworthy except Uqba bin Abdul-Rahman who is Ibn Abi Ma'mar and is unknown (Majhul) as in "Al-Taqrib". Do not be deceived by Al-Haythami's saying (2 / 27): "Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Kabir and its men are trustworthy (Muwaththaqun)" what Al-Shawkani did, for he said (2 / 114) "and its chain is Jayyid". This is because saying "Muwaththaqun" is less than saying "Thiqat" (trustworthy). Their saying "Muwaththaqun" is an indication from them that some of its narrators' authentication is not strong. It is as if Al-Haythami is indicating that this Uqba was only authenticated by Ibn Hibban and that Ibn Hibban's authentication is not reliable, and Allah knows best. The fact that Ibn Hibban's authentication is not reliable is something not doubted by those deeply versed in this noble science. I have detailed this in my reply to the treatise "Al-Ta'aqub Al-Hathith" by Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi, published in Al-Tamaddun Al-Islami in consecutive articles, then published in a separate treatise titled "Al-Radd 'ala Al-Ta'aqub Al-Hathith", so refer to (p. 18-21). Furthermore, saying about a hadith "its men are trustworthy" or "its men are men of Sahih" does not mean that its chain is authentic as I clarified elsewhere. See for example "Silsilat Al-Ahadith Al-Sahihah" (Vol. 2 p. 5 Al-Maktab Al-Islami print). However, the hadith is authentic due to its previous witnesses.

text: And he has (2 / 241) a witness from the hadith of Abu Umamah, and a second witness narrated by Al-Tabarani from Ka'b bin Malik with a chain that has no harm as Ibn Hajar Al-Haytami said in "Al-Zawajir" (1 / 120), and Al-Hafiz Nur Al-Din Al-Haythami weakened it in "Majma' Al-Zawa'id" (9 / 45).

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Narrated by Ahmad (Numbers 1691, 1694), Al-Tahawi in "Mushkil Al-Athar" (4 / 13), Abu Ya'la (57 / 1), and Ibn Asakir (8 / 367 / 2) with an authentic chain. Al-Haythami said in "Al-Majma'" (5 / 325): Narrated by Ahmad with chains (Original: with two chains) and the men of two of them are trustworthy, their chain is connected. And Abu Ya'la narrated it. I say: There is a clear observation on this statement because the pivot of the three paths he referred to is Ibrahim bin Maymun from Saad bin Samura, except that the third path had some narrators insert Ishaq bin Saad bin Samura between them, which is a mistake as clarified by Al-Hafiz in "Al-Ta'jeel". Also, it does not contain "and know that the worst of people..." Then Al-Haythami mentioned this hadith elsewhere (2 / 82) similarly and said: Narrated by Al-Bazzar and its men are trustworthy. It has a Mursal witness from Umar bin Abdul-Aziz raised similarly. Narrated by Ibn Saad (2 / 254).

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: From Abu Huraira, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "O Allah, do not make my grave an idol (26). Allah cursed a people who took the graves of their prophets as mosques." (27)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 12 - From Abdullah bin Mas'ud, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, saying: Indeed, among the worst of people are those upon whom the Hour comes while they are alive, and those who take graves as mosques. (28) (27) - Narrated by Ahmad (Number 7352), Ibn Saad (2 / 241-242), Al-Mufaddal Al-Jandi in "Fada'il Al-Madina" (66 / 1), Abu Ya'la in his "Musnad" (312 / 1), Al-Humaydi (1025), and Abu Nu'aym in "Al-Hilya" (6 / 382 & 7 / 317) with an authentic chain. It has a Mursal witness narrated by Abdur-Razzaq in "Al-Musannaf" (1 / 406 / 1587) and likewise Ibn Abi Shaybah (4 / 141) from Zaid bin Aslam. Its chain is strong. (26) - "Ibn Abd al-Barr said: Wathan means idol. He says: Do not make my grave an idol to be prayed to, prostrated towards, and worshipped. Allah's wrath has intensified against those who do that. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was warning his companions and his entire Ummah against the bad deed of previous nations who prayed to the graves of their prophets and took them as Qibla and mosque, as the idolaters did with idols they prostrated to and venerated. That is the major Shirk. The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, was informing them of Allah's displeasure and wrath in that, and that it is something He does not approve of, fearing for them to follow their ways. He, peace be upon him, loved opposing the People of the Book and all disbelievers, and he feared for his Ummah to follow them. Do you not see his saying, peace be upon him, by way of rebuke and reprimand 'You will surely follow the ways of those before you, step by step, even if one of them entered a lizard's hole, you would enter it?'" So in "Fath Al-Bari" by Ibn Rajab (65 / 90 / 2) from "Al-Kawakib". (28) - Narrated by Ibn Khuzaimah in his "Sahih" (1 / 92 / 2), Ibn Hibban (340 & 341), Ibn Abi Shaybah in "Al-Musannaf" (4 / 140 Indian print), Ahmad (Numbers 3844 & 4143), Al-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (3 / 77 / 1), Abu Ya'la in his "Musnad" (257 / 1), and Abu Nu'aym in "Akhbar Isfahan" (1 / 142) with a Hasan chain. And Ahmad also (Number 4342) with another Hasan chain supporting the previous one. The hadith by their sum is authentic. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Minhaj Al-Sunnah" (1311) and "Al-Iqtida" (p. 185): "And its chain is Jayyid (good)". Al-Haythami said (2 / 27): "Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Kabir and its chain is Hasan." His limitation in attribution to Al-Tabarani alone is an apparent deficiency, while it is in the Musnad in three places as we indicated just now. The first part of the hadith was narrated by Al-Bukhari in his Sahih (13 / 15) suspended (Mu'allaq).

text: 13 - From Ali bin Abi Talib, he said: Al-Abbas met me and said: O Ali, let us go to the Prophet, peace be upon him. If there is something of command for us, or else he recommends people regarding us. So we entered upon him while he was unconscious. He raised his head and said: Allah cursed the Jews; they took the graves of prophets as mosques." Added in a narration: "Then he said it a third time." When we saw his condition, we left and did not ask him anything. (29)

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Chapter Two

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: The Meaning of Taking Graves as Mosques It has become clear from the previous hadiths the danger of taking graves as mosques and the severe threat from Allah Almighty upon whoever does that. We must understand the meaning of the mentioned taking so we can avoid it. I say: What can be understood from this taking is only three meanings: (29) - Narrated by Ibn Saad (4 / 28) and Ibn Asakir (12 / 172 / 2) from two paths from Uthman Ibn Al-Yaman told us Abu Bakr Ibn Abi Awn that he heard Abdullah bin Isa bin Abdul-Rahman bin Abi Laila from his father from his grandfather or said: from his father or from his grandfather said: I heard Ali bin Abi Talib say: I say: This chain is Hasan were it not that I do not know this Abu Bakr, and Al-Dawlabi and Abu Ahmad Al-Hakim did not mention him in "Al-Kuna". (30) - Narrated by Ibn Zanjawayh in "Fada'il Al-Siddiq" as in "Al-Jami' Al-Kabir" (3 / 147 / 1).

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: First: Praying on graves meaning prostrating on them. Second: Prostrating towards them and facing them in prayer and supplication. Third: Building mosques over them and intending to pray in them. Scholars' Statements on the Meaning of the Mentioned Taking A group of scholars held each of these meanings, and explicit texts came with them from the Master of Prophets, peace be upon him. As for the first, Ibn Hajar Al-Haytami said in "Al-Zawajir" (1 / 121): Taking the grave as a mosque means praying on it or towards it. This is a text from him that he understands the mentioned taking as including two meanings, one of which is praying on the grave. Al-San'ani said in "Subul Al-Salam" (1 / 214): "Taking graves as mosques is more general than meaning praying towards them or meaning praying on them." I say: Meaning it includes both meanings, and it is possible that he intended the three meanings, which is what Imam Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, understood, and his text on that will come. Witnesses for the first meaning are hadiths: First: From Abu Saeed Al-Khudri: "That the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade building over graves, sitting on them, or praying on them." (31) Second: His saying, peace be upon him: "Do not pray towards a grave nor pray on a grave." (32) Third: From Anas: That the Prophet, peace be upon him, forbade... and was asked about praying amidst graves. He said: It was mentioned to me that the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "The Children of Israel took the graves of their prophets as mosques, so Allah Almighty cursed them." (33) As for the second meaning: Al-Munawi said in "Fayd Al-Qadir" explaining the third hadith mentioned above: Meaning they took them as their Qibla direction with their false belief. Taking them as mosques necessitates (34) taking mosques over them and vice versa. He clarified by this the reason for their cursing due to the exaggeration in veneration. Al-Qadi (meaning Al-Baydawi) said: Since the Jews used to prostrate to the graves of their prophets out of veneration for their status and make them a Qibla and turn towards them in prayer, taking them as idols, Allah cursed them and prevented Muslims from the like of that and forbade them from it. I say: This is a meaning explicitly forbidden, so he, peace be upon him, said: Do not sit on graves nor pray towards them. (35)

text: 1 - He said on "p. 20": Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Do not benefit from the dead animal (carrion) in any way." Narrated by Al-Daraqutni with a good chain. I say: It is a weak hadith, and there is something in the Sahih that contradicts it. Attributing it to Al-Daraqutni is an illusion; I have not found anyone who preceded him in this.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 2 - He said on "p. 28" regarding his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Whoever cleanses himself from wind (flatulence), he is not of us," narrated by Al-Tabarani in his "Al-Mu'jam Al-Saghir." I say: This is not in the "Mu'jam," and I inform the people of this, and praise be to Allah, for I have served it and arranged it according to the Musnads of the Companions, extracted its hadiths, and created a comprehensive index for its hadiths. Furthermore, being certain about attributing it to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is questionable because it is from the narration of Abu Al-Zubayr from Jabir, as extracted by Al-Jurjani (272) and others, and Abu Al-Zubayr is a Mudallis (one who obfuscates chains) and used the 'an'anah form (saying 'from').

text: 3 - He said on "p. 29": The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "The smell of the mouth of a fasting person..." narrated by Al-Tirmidhi. I say: It is in "Sahih Al-Bukhari" and "Sahih Muslim."

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in "Al-Mirqah" (2 / 372) explaining the reasoning for the prohibition: "Because of the excessive veneration involved, as if it were the rank of the Worshipped. If this veneration were truly for the grave or its occupant, the one venerating would commit disbelief (Kufr). Thus, imitating it is disliked (Makruh), and the dislike should be that of prohibition (Tahrim). Similar to it regarding meaning, or even more so, is the funeral (Janazah) placed (meaning as the Qiblah of the worshippers). This is a trial that the people of Mecca have been afflicted with, where they place the funeral near the Kaaba and then face towards it." I say: He means during the obligatory prayer. This is a general affliction that has spread to the lands of Sham, Anatolia, and others. We came across a very ugly photograph a month ago depicting a row of worshippers prostrating towards coffins lined up in front of them containing the bodies of a group of Turks who had died drowning in a ship. On this occasion, we draw attention to the fact that the predominant guidance of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was to pray over funerals in the "Musalla" (place of prayer) outside the mosque. Perhaps one of the wisdoms behind that is to keep the worshippers far from falling into such violations as warned by the scholar Al-Qari (may Allah have mercy on him). Similar to the previous hadith is what Thabit Al-Bunani narrated from Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: I was praying near a grave, so Omar bin Al-Khattab saw me and said: "The grave, the grave!" So I raised my sight to the sky, thinking he was saying: "The moon" (36). As for the third meaning: Imam Al-Bukhari held this view, for he titled the first hadith with his saying: "Chapter: What is disliked regarding taking graves as a place of worship upon the graves." He indicated by this that the prohibition of taking graves as a place of worship necessitates the prohibition of building mosques upon them. This is a clear matter, and Al-Manawi explicitly stated it recently. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in the explanation of the hadith: "Al-Kirmani said: The implication of the hadith is the prevention of taking the grave as a mosque, and the meaning of the chapter title is taking a mosque upon the grave; their concepts are different. It is answered that they are concomitant, even if the concepts differ."

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: This meaning is what Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) pointed to in her statement at the end of the first hadith: "If not for that, his grave would have been made prominent, but he feared it would be taken as a mosque." The meaning is: If not for that curse which the Jews and Christians deserved because of their taking graves as mosques—which necessitates building upon them—his grave (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) would have been made in prominent, exposed land. However, the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them) did not do that for fear that a mosque would be built upon it by some of those who come after them, thus including them in the curse. This is supported by what Ibn Sa'd narrated (2 / 241) with a Sahih chain from Al-Hasan (Al-Basri) who said: They consulted (37) about burying him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the mosque, so Aisha said: Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had his head placed in my lap when he said: "May Allah kill peoples who took the graves of their prophets as mosques." So their opinion settled on burying him where his soul was taken, in Aisha's house. I say: This narration, despite being Mursal (hurried), indicates two things: First: That Aisha understood from the "taking" mentioned in the hadith that it includes the mosque which might encompass the grave, so it applies even more so to the mosque built upon the grave. Second: That the Companions confirmed her on this understanding, and thus they returned to her opinion and buried him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in her house. This indicates that there is no difference between building a mosque on the grave or introducing the grave into the mosque; all is forbidden (Haram) because the concern is one. Therefore, Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said: "If one builds a mosque intending to be buried in part of it, he enters into the curse. Rather, burial in the mosque is forbidden, and even if it is stipulated that he be buried in it, the stipulation is invalid due to its contradiction with designating it as a mosque" (38).

38. - Al-Manawi quoted it in "Fayd al-Qadir" (5 / 274) and affirmed it.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: I say: In this is an indication that the mosque and the grave do not combine in the religion of Islam, as mentioned previously and will be mentioned. This meaning is witnessed by the fifth hadith mentioned earlier with the wording: "Those are a people who, when a righteous man among them died, built a mosque over his grave... Those are the worst of creation..." It is an explicit text regarding the prohibition of building a mosque over the graves of prophets and the righteous, because he stated that it is one of the causes for them being the worst of creation in the sight of Allah the Exalted. It is supported by the hadith of Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade plastering the grave, sitting on it, and building over it" (39). Due to its generality, it includes building a mosque over the grave, just as it includes building a dome over it; rather, the former is more deserving of prohibition, as is obvious. Thus, it is established that this meaning is also correct, indicated by the word "taking" (Itikhadh) and supported by other evidences. As for the inclusion of the prohibition of praying in mosques built over graves in the hadiths, its indication is even clearer. This is because prohibiting the building of mosques over graves necessitates prohibiting prayer within them, based on the principle that prohibiting the means necessitates prohibiting the intended end and using it as a means to that end. An example of this is: If the Lawgiver forbids selling alcohol, then the prohibition of drinking it is included in that, as is obvious; rather, the prohibition is a fortiori. It is very clear that prohibiting the building of mosques over graves is not intended for itself, just as the command to build mosques in neighborhoods and localities is not intended for itself, but all of that is for the sake of prayer within them, negatively or positively. The following example clarifies this: If a man built a mosque in a desolate place, uninhabited and visited by no one for prayer, this man would have no reward for building this mosque; rather, in my view, he is sinful for wasting money and placing a thing in other than its place. So if the Lawgiver commands building mosques, He implicitly commands praying in them because that is the purpose of the building. Likewise, if He forbids building mosques over graves, He implicitly forbids praying in them because that is the purpose of the building as well. This is clear and not hidden from a rational person, Allah willing. Preference for the hadith covering all meanings and Al-Shafi'i's statement on that. Summary of the speech: The "taking" mentioned in the previous hadiths includes all these three meanings. It is from his (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) comprehensive speech. Imam Al-Shafi'i (may Allah have mercy on him) held this view. In his book "Al-Umm" (1 / 246), the text reads: "I dislike that a mosque be built over a grave, or that it be leveled or prayed upon while it is not leveled (meaning it is prominent and known) or prayed towards." He said: "And if he prays towards it, it suffices him, but he has done wrong. Malik informed us that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'May Allah kill the Jews and Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques.'" He said: "I dislike this due to the Sunnah and the relics (Athar), and strictly dislike—and Allah knows best—that anyone of the Muslims be venerated (meaning his grave be taken as a mosque) and there is no safety in that from Fitnah (trial) and misguidance for those who come after him."

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Know that this hadith of Jabir regarding the prohibition of building over the grave is a Sahih hadith; no one with knowledge of the methods of authentication and weakening doubts that. So do not be deceived by Al-Kawthari's defecting of it in his "Maqalat" (p. 159) claiming that "it contains the 'an'anah (saying 'from') of Abu Al-Zubayr." For Ibn Al-Zubayr explicitly stated he heard it (Tahdith) in Muslim and likewise in Ahmad. I do not believe this is hidden from Al-Kawthari, but he does that deliberately, which is the habit of the people of desires (Ahl al-Ahwa), ancient and modern; they weaken Sahih hadiths if they are against them and authenticate weak hadiths if they are for them. This Al-Kawthari is famous for that among the people of knowledge, and I have clarified some of this in "The Weak and Fabricated Hadiths and Their Evil Effect on the Nation" (Hadiths 23, 24, and 25), so let whoever wishes to verify what we say refer to it. Another example will come to you in this book. Supporting the authenticity of the hadith is that Abu Al-Zubayr was not alone in narrating it; rather, Suleiman bin Musa followed him in Ahmad and others. When Al-Tirmidhi authenticated it, he said: "It has been narrated from more than one path from Jabir." Abu Nadrah also followed him in Ibn Al-Najjar's "Tail of the History of Baghdad" (10 / 201 / 1). It has a corroborating evidence (Shahid) from Umm Salamah in Ahmad, and another from Abu Sa'id as in "Al-Kawakib Al-Darari" (Folio 86-87 Tafsir 548).

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: He inferred from the hadith the three meanings mentioned in the context of his speech, so it is clear evidence that he understands the hadith in its generality. The researcher Sheikh Ali Al-Qari did likewise, quoting some Imams of the Hanafis, saying in "Mirqat al-Mafatih Sharh Mishkat al-Masabih" (1 / 45): "The reason for cursing them: Either because they used to prostrate to the graves of their prophets out of veneration for them, and that is clear Shirk (Polytheism). Or because they used to undertake prayer to Allah the Exalted in the burial places of the prophets, and prostration upon their graves, and facing towards their graves during prayer, considering that as worship of Allah and exaggeration in venerating the prophets. That is hidden Shirk, because it contains what amounts to venerating a created being in a way not permitted. So the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade his nation from that, either due to the resemblance of that action to the way of the Jews or to eliminate hidden Shirk. This was said by some commentators from our Imams. It is supported by what came in a narration: 'He warns against what they did.'" I say: The first reason he mentioned, which is prostrating to the graves of prophets out of veneration for them, even if its occurrence among Jews and Christians is not unlikely, it is not what immediately comes to mind from his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "They took the graves of their prophets as mosques." For its apparent meaning is that they took them as mosques for the worship of Allah within them according to the previous meanings, seeking blessings through those buried therein from the prophets. Even if this led them, as it leads others, to fall into clear Shirk, as Sheikh Al-Qari mentioned.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Chapter Three

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Taking Mosques upon Graves is among the Major Sins. After the meaning of "taking" mentioned in the previous hadiths has become clear to us, it is appropriate for us to pause a little at these hadiths to recognize from them the ruling of the mentioned "taking," guided in that by what scholars have mentioned about it. I say: Everyone who contemplates those noble hadiths will see in a manner that leaves no doubt that the mentioned "taking" is forbidden, rather it is a major sin among the Major Sins (Kabir). This is because the curse mentioned in them and the description of the violators as being the worst of creation in the sight of Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, cannot be applied to one who commits something that is not a major sin, as is not hidden regarding the schools of the scholars on this. The four schools of thought have agreed on the prohibition of that, and some of them have explicitly stated that it is a major sin. Here are the details of the schools on that:

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: 1 - The Shafi'i School: It is a major sin. The jurist Ibn Hajar Al-Haytami said in "Al-Zawajir 'an Iqtiraf Al-Kaba'ir" (The Deterrents from Committing Major Sins) (1 / 120): "The ninety-third, ninety-fourth, ninety-fifth, ninety-sixth, ninety-seventh, and ninety-eighth major sins are: Taking graves as mosques, lighting lamps upon them, taking them as idols, circumambulating them, touching them (for blessing), and praying towards them." Then he cited some of the previously mentioned hadiths and others, then said (p. 111): "[Note]: Counting these six as major sins occurred in the speech of some Shafi'is, and it seems he took that from what I mentioned of the hadiths. The reason for taking a grave as a mosque being one of them is clear, because he cursed the one who did that with the graves of his prophets, and made those who do that with the graves of their righteous ones the worst of creation in the sight of Allah the Exalted on the Day of Resurrection. In this is a warning to us, as in the narration: 'He warns against what they did,' meaning he warns his nation by saying that to them, lest they do as those did and be cursed as they were cursed. Hence our companions said: Praying towards the graves of prophets and saints for blessing and veneration is forbidden, and similar to it is praying upon it for blessing and veneration. That this action is a major sin is apparent from the mentioned hadiths, as you have known." Some Hanbalis said:

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: "A man's intention to pray at a grave seeking blessing by it is the essence of opposing Allah and His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and innovating a religion that Allah did not authorize, due to the prohibition against it. Then, by consensus, the greatest of prohibitions and causes of Shirk is praying at them and taking them as mosques or building over them. The saying of 'dislike' (Karahah) is interpreted as other than that [i.e., prohibition], for it is not thought of the scholars that they would permit an action for which the doer is cursed by Mutawatir narration from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). It is obligatory to rush to demolish them and demolish the domes over the graves, for they are more harmful than the Mosque of Harm (Masjid al-Dirar) because they were founded on disobedience to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), as he forbade that. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) commanded the demolition of elevated graves. It is obligatory to remove every lantern or lamp on a grave, and its endowment (Waqf) and vow (Nadhr) are not valid. End quote." All of this is the speech of the jurist Ibn Hajar Al-Haytami, and the researcher Al-Alusi affirmed him in "Ruh al-Ma'ani" (5 / 31). It is speech that indicates understanding and jurisprudence in the religion. His saying regarding what he quoted from some Hanbalis: "The saying of 'dislike' is interpreted as other than that," seems to point to Shafi'i's saying "And I dislike that a mosque be built over a grave..." etc., his speech which I quoted in full previously (p. 27). His followers among the Shafi'is are upon this, as in "Al-Tahdhib" and its explanation "Al-Majmu'." It is strange that they argue for this using some of the previously mentioned hadiths, even though they are explicit in prohibiting it and cursing the doer. If 'dislike' meant prohibition to them, the matter would be close, but for them, it is for purification (Tanzih). So how does the saying of (Karahah/Dislike) align with those hadiths they use as evidence for it? I say this, although I do not rule out interpreting 'dislike' in Shafi'i's previous statement specifically as Prohibitive Dislike (Karahah Tahrimiyyah), because that is the intended Sharia meaning in Quranic usage. There is no doubt that Shafi'i is influenced by the style of the Quran to the utmost degree. So if we find in his speech a term that has a special meaning in the Holy Quran, it is obligatory to interpret it according to that, not according to the meaning coined by later scholars. For Allah the Exalted said: {But He has made hateful [karraha] to you disbelief, defiance, and disobedience} (40). These are all forbidden things. This meaning, and Allah knows best, is what Shafi'i (may Allah have mercy on him) intended by his previous saying "And I dislike." It is known to everyone who has studied this issue with its evidences that there is no evidence diverting the prohibition mentioned in some of the previous hadiths to anything other than Tahrim. How could there be, when the hadiths confirm it is for Tahrim as previously mentioned? Therefore, I am certain that Tahrim is the view of Shafi'i, especially since he explicitly stated the dislike after mentioning the hadith "May Allah kill the Jews and Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques" as mentioned before. So it is no surprise then if Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi, who is Shafi'i in Madhhab, explicitly stated the prohibition of building a mosque over a grave as previously mentioned. And Allah knows best. For this reason, we say: He erred who attributed to Imam Shafi'i the opinion permitting a man to marry his daughter from Zina (adultery) based on the argument that he explicitly stated the "dislike" of that, and dislike does not negate permissibility if it is for Tanzih (purification/preference). Ibn al-Qayyim said in "I'lam al-Muwaqqi'in" (1 / 47-48): "Shafi'i stated the dislike of a man marrying his daughter from the water of Zina, and he never said it is permissible or allowed. He used the term 'dislike' because the Haram is disliked by Allah and His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). He was asked: Is prayer valid in a mosque if there is a grave in it and people gather in it for congregational and Friday prayers or not? If the mosque was before the burial, it is changed either by leveling the grave or by exhuming it if it is new. book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Doubts and their Answers. A speaker might say: If the prohibition of building mosques over graves is established in the Sharia, there are many matters indicating the contrary. Here is their clarification: First: His saying, the Exalted, in Surah Al-Kahf: {Said those who prevailed in the matter, "We will surely take [for ourselves] over them a mosque"} (55). The aspect of the verse's indication of that: Those who said this statement were Christians as mentioned in the books of Tafsir, so taking a mosque over a grave was part of their Sharia, and the Sharia of those before us is a Sharia for us if Allah mentioned it and did not follow it with what indicates its rejection, as in this noble verse. Second: The presence of the grave of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in his noble mosque. If that were not permissible, they would not have buried him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in his mosque. Third: The prayer of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in Masjid al-Khaif even though there are the graves of seventy prophets in it, as he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said. Fourth: What is mentioned in some books that the grave of Ismail (peace be upon him) and others are in the Hijr of the Sacred Mosque, which is the best mosque for a worshipper to seek. Fifth: Abu Jandal (may Allah be pleased with him) building a mosque over the grave of Abu Basir (may Allah be pleased with him) during the time of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as stated in "Al-Isti'ab" by Ibn Abd al-Barr. Sixth: Some claimed that the prevention of taking graves as mosques was due to the reason of fearing trial (Fitnah) by the buried person, and this was removed by the firmness of Monotheism (Tawhid) in the hearts of the believers, so the prevention is removed.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: The Answer to the First Doubt: As for the first doubt, the answer to it is from three aspects: First: The correct view established in the science of Principles (Usul) is that the Sharia of those before us is not a Sharia for us due to many evidences (56), among them his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "I was given five things which no one of the prophets before me was given... (and he mentioned them, ending with) and a Prophet used to be sent to his people specifically, and I have been sent to all mankind" (57). If this is clear, we are not obligated to take what is in the verse even if it indicated that the permissibility of building a mosque over a grave was a Sharia for those before us. Second: Suppose the correct view is the saying of those who say: "The Sharia of those before us is a Sharia for us." That is conditional upon there being nothing in our Sharia that contradicts it. This condition is absent here because the hadiths are Mutawatir (consecutive/abundant) in forbidding the mentioned building as previously stated. That is proof that what is in the verse is not a Sharia for us. Third: We do not concede that the verse implies that this was a Sharia for those before us. The most it contains is that a group of people said: {We will surely take [for ourselves] over them a mosque}. It does not explicitly state that they were believers. Even if conceded, it does not imply they were righteous believers adhering to the Sharia of a sent prophet; rather, the apparent meaning is the opposite. Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab said in "Fath al-Bari fi Sharh al-Bukhari" (65 / 280) from "Al-Kawakib Al-Darari" (58): "The hadith 'May Allah curse the Jews who took the graves of their prophets as mosques.' The Quran has indicated something similar to what this hadith indicated, which is the saying of Allah the Mighty and Majestic in the story of the Companions of the Cave: {Said those who prevailed in the matter, 'We will surely take [for ourselves] over them a mosque'}. He made taking graves as mosques the action of those who prevailed in matters, which implies that its basis is coercion, dominance, and following desires, and that it is not the action of the people of knowledge and virtue who support what Allah sent to His messengers of guidance." Sheikh Ali bin Urwah said in "Mukhtasar al-Kawakib" (10 / 207 / 2) following Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir in his Tafsir (3 / 78): Ibn Jarir narrated two opinions regarding those who said that (59): One of them: That they were the Muslims among them. The second: The people of Shirk among them. Allah knows best. The apparent meaning is that those who said that were the people of power and influence. But are they praiseworthy or not? There is a question in that because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "May Allah curse the Jews and Christians; they took the graves of their prophets as mosques," warning against what they did. We have narrated from Omar bin Al-Khattab that when he found the grave of Daniel in Iraq during his time, he commanded that it be hidden from the people and that the parchment found with him containing some epics and other things be buried." If you know this, it is not correct to use the verse as evidence in any way. The researcher scholar Al-Alusi said in "Ruh al-Ma'ani" (5 / 31): "Using the verse as evidence for the permissibility of building over the graves of scholars, taking a mosque over them, and the permissibility of prayer in that has been done by some, among them Al-Shihab Al-Khafaji in his footnotes on Al-Baydawi. It is a false, idle, corrupt, and stagnant saying, for it has been narrated..."

It is appropriate for everyone to demolish that as long as no corruption is feared from it; otherwise, the removal is designated to the Imam, taking from the speech of Ibn Al-Rif'ah regarding reconciliation." End quote. Then Imam Al-Alusi said: "Do not say: The verse is apparent in that what was mentioned is from the Sharia of those before us, and it has been used as evidence. For it has been narrated that he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'Whoever sleeps through a prayer or forgets it...' (60) the hadith, then he recited His saying {And establish prayer for My remembrance} (20:14), which was said to Moses (peace be upon him), and its context is evidentiary. And Abu Yusuf argued for retaliation (Qisas) occurring between male and female using the verse {And We ordained for them therein...}, and Al-Karkhi argued for it occurring between the free and the slave, and the Muslim and the Dhirnmi (61) using that verse revealed regarding the Children of Israel, and so on. For we say: Our school regarding the Sharia of those before us, even if it is binding upon us as our Sharia, implies that it is not absolute. Rather, if Allah narrated it to us without rejection, [then rejection] by His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is like rejection by Him, the Mighty and Majestic (62). And you have heard that he (peace and blessings upon him) cursed those who take mosques over graves. Furthermore, that what was mentioned is from the laws of those before us is prohibited. How can taking mosques over graves be from the earlier Sharias given what you have heard of the cursing of the Jews and Christians for taking the graves of their prophets as mosques? The verse is not like the verses we mentioned just now regarding the Imams' argumentation with them. It contains nothing more than a narration of the saying of a group of people and their determination to do that. It does not come in the context of praising them or urging emulation of them. Thus, when it is not established that there was an infallible person among them, their action or determination does not indicate the legitimacy of what they were about to do."

text: "What strengthens the lack of confidence in their action is the saying that the intended meaning refers to the rulers and sultans, as narrated from Qatada. Based on this, one can say: The first group were believers who knew the illegitimacy of taking mosques over graves, so they advised building over the entrance of the cave and blocking it, and stopping interference with its occupants. But the rulers did not accept from them, and this angered them until they swore to take a mosque. If you insist on having a good opinion of the second group, you can say: Their taking a mosque over them is not in the manner of taking mosques over graves which is forbidden and whose doer is cursed. Rather, it is taking a mosque near them and close to their cave. The explicit mention of 'indiyyah' (at/nearness) came in the narration of the story from Al-Suddi and Wahb. Such taking is not prohibited, as the most that follows from it is that the relation of the mosque to the cave understood from it is like the relation of the Prophet's Mosque to the Noble Shrine (may Allah bless and grant peace to the one in it). His saying {We will surely take... over them} would be, in this manner, like the saying of the group (Build over them). Or if you wish, say: That taking was on a cave above the mountain in which they were. There is a report from Mujahid that the King left them in their cave and built a mosque over their cave. This is closer to the apparent wording, as is obvious. All of this is needed only on the saying that the Companions of the Cave died after they were discovered. As for the saying that they slept as they slept the first time, there is no need for it as has been said (63). In summary, it is not appropriate for anyone with the slightest guidance to go against what the authentic reports and explicit narrations have articulated, relying on reasoning with this verse. For that is the utmost error and the end of lack of intelligence. I have seen those who permit what the ignorant do regarding the graves of the righteous—raising them, building them with gypsum and bricks, hanging lanterns on them, praying towards them, circumambulating them, touching them, and gathering at them at specific times, etc.—arguing with this noble verse and with what came in some narrations of the story about the King making a feast for them every year and placing them in coffins of teak. They draw analogies of one to another. All of that is opposing Allah the Exalted and His Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and innovating a religion that Allah the Mighty and Majestic did not authorize. It suffices you in knowing the truth to follow what the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did regarding his grave (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), which is the best grave on the face of the earth, and understanding their actions in visiting him and greeting him. So follow that and contemplate what is here and what is there, and Allah the Glorious will take charge of your guidance." I say: Some contemporaries (64) have used the mentioned verse as evidence for the alleged permissibility, rather the desirability, of building mosques over graves. But from another innovated perspective slightly different from what was previously narrated and refuted. He said:

This is supported by the following aspect: Second: The mentioned deduction only stands according to the method of the people of desires from the past and contemporaries who suffice with the Quran regarding religion and do not give weight to the Sunnah. The answer: This, although it is what is seen today, was not the case during the time of the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them). When the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) died, they buried him in his room which was next to his mosque, and a wall separated them containing a door from which the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to exit to the mosque. This is a known matter, decisive among scholars, and there is no dispute about it among them. When the Companions (may Allah be pleased with them) buried him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in the room, they did so only so that no one after them could take his grave as a mosque, as previously explained in the hadith of Aisha and others (p. 9-10). However, something happened after them that was not in their calculation. That is that Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik commanded in the year eighty-eight to demolish the Prophet's Mosque and add the rooms of the wives of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to it. So he introduced the Prophetic Room—Aisha's room—into it, and thus the grave became inside the mosque (68). There was no one from the Companions in Medina at that time, contrary to what some have imagined. The Scholar Al-Hafiz Muhammad Ibn Abd al-Hadi said in "Al-Sarim Al-Munki" (p. 136):

text: In summary, we do not have any text that can serve as evidence that any of the Companions were present during this time of change. Whoever claims otherwise must provide proof. As for what appears in Sharh Muslim (5/1314) that this occurred during the time of the Companions, perhaps his basis is that problematic (mu'dal) or disconnected (mursal) narration. Such narrations cannot serve as proof, especially since it is more specific than the claim; for even if it were authentic, it would only prove the existence of *one* of the Companions at that time, not "the Companions" [as a group]. As for the claim of some who have written on this issue without knowledge: "Since Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, expanded the Prophet's Mosque and included in the mosque what was not part of it, and the three graves became surrounded by the mosque, no one from the Salaf denied that," this is from their limitless ignorance. I do not wish to say it is from their fabrications, for no scholar has ever said that the inclusion of the three graves occurred during the time of Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him. Rather, they agreed that it happened during the reign of Al-Walid bin Abdul-Malik, as mentioned before, which is about half a century after Uthman. But they speak of what they do not know. This is because Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, did the opposite of what they attributed to him. When he expanded the noble Prophet's Mosque, he was careful to avoid violating the hadiths referred to, so he did not expand the mosque from the side of the chambers and did not include them in it. This is exactly what his predecessor, Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with them all, did. Rather, he indicated that expanding from the side referred to contains the prohibition mentioned in the previous hadiths, as will be mentioned from him shortly.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: As for their saying: "And no one from the Salaf denied that," we say: How do you know that? For one of the most difficult things for rational people is to prove the negation of something that could have happened but was not known, as is well known among scholars. This is because it requires complete induction and comprehensive knowledge of everything that happened and was said about the incident regarding which the matter is to be negated. And how could such people do that, even if they were capable? If they had reviewed some books on this issue, they would not have fallen into that scandalous ignorance, and they would have found what would prevent them from not denying what they did not fully know. For Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said in his history (Vol. 9, p. 75) after mentioning the story of the inclusion of the Prophet's grave into the mosque: "It is reported that Said bin Al-Musayyib denied the inclusion of Aisha's chamber into the mosque, as if he feared that the grave would be taken as a mosque." It does not matter much to me whether this narration is authentic or not, because we do not base a legal ruling on it. But the assumption about Said bin Al-Musayyib and other scholars who witnessed that change is that they denied it most vehemently because it clearly contradicts the previous hadiths, especially the narration of Aisha which says: "Were it not for that, his grave would have been made prominent, but it was feared that it might be taken as a mosque." What the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, feared has unfortunately happened with the inclusion of the grave into the mosque. For there is no difference between burying him, peace and blessings be upon him, in the mosque when he died—far be it from them to do so—and what those after them did by including his grave into the mosque through its expansion. The prohibition is present in any case, as previously mentioned from Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi and Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah. This assumption is supported by the fact that Said bin Al-Musayyib is one of the narrators of the second hadith as mentioned before. Is it fitting for someone who acknowledges his knowledge, virtue, and boldness in the truth to think that he denied those who contradicted the hadith he narrated, or to attribute to him the lack of denial, as claimed by those referred to when they said "no one from the Salaf denied that"?

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: The truth is that their statement implies a clear defamation of all the Salaf, if they only knew. For including the grave in the mosque is a clear evil (munkar) to anyone aware of the aforementioned hadiths and their meanings. It is impossible to attribute ignorance of this to all the Salaf; they, or at least some of them, knew this with certainty. If this is the case, it must be said that they denied it, even if we have not come across a text regarding it, because history has not preserved everything that happened for us. So how can it be said: "They did not deny that"? O Allah, forgive! Among their ignorance is their statement, following their previous one: "And likewise the Umayyad Mosque; the Muslims entered Damascus, including Companions and others, and the grave was within the mosque, yet no one denied that." Their logic is strange and bizarre. They imagine that everything they see now in the Umayyad Mosque existed during the time of its first builder, Al-Walid bin Abdul-Malik. Would any rational person say this? No, no one says that except these people. We assert the invalidity of their statement and that none of the Companions or Tabi'in saw a visible grave in the Umayyad Mosque or elsewhere. Rather, the most that has been reported in some narrations from Zaid bin Arqam bin Waqid is that during the operations, they found a cave containing a box with a basket (a complete container), and in the basket was the head of John the son of Zechariah (Yahya bin Zakariya), peace be upon them, with writing on it: "This is the head of Yahya, peace be upon him." Al-Walid ordered it to be returned to its place and said: "Make the pillar above it different from the other pillars." So a pillar shaped like a basket for the head was placed over it. Narrated by Abu Al-Hasan Al-Raba'i in Fada'il Al-Sham (33), and via him Ibn Asakir in his history (Vol. 2, Folio 9/10). Its chain of narration is very weak; it contains Ibrahim bin Hisham Al-Ghassani, whom Abu Hatim and Abu Zur'ah declared a liar, and Al-Dhahabi said he is "abandoned" (matruk). Despite this, we assert that there was no image of a grave in the mosque until the late second century, based on what Al-Raba'i and Ibn Asakir narrated from Al-Walid bin Muslim, who was asked, "Where did you hear the head of Yahya bin Zakariya is?" He said: "I heard it is there," and pointed with his hand to the basket-shaped pillar, the fourth from the eastern corner. This indicates that there was no grave there during the time of Al-Walid bin Muslim, and he died in the year 194 AH.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: As for whether that head is indeed the head of Yahya, peace be upon him, it cannot be proven. Therefore, historians have differed greatly, and the majority hold that the head of Yahya, peace be upon him, is buried in the mosque of Aleppo, not in the mosque of Damascus, as verified by our Sheikh in Ijazah (authorization), the scholar Muhammad Raghib Al-Tabbakh, in a research he published in the Journal of the Arab Scientific Academy in Damascus (Vol. 1, p. 41, 1482) under the title "The Head of Yahya and the Head of Zakariya." Let whoever wishes refer to it. From a religious perspective, it does not matter to us whether this or that is proven. Whether the noble head is in this mosque or that one is the same to us. Indeed, even if we were certain of its absence in both mosques, the existence of the image of a grave in them is sufficient for it to be a violation, because the rulings of the purified Sharia are based on the apparent, not the hidden, as is well known. Testimony to this from the words of some scholars will follow. The violation is most severe if the grave is in the qibla of the mosque, as is the case in the mosque of Aleppo, and there is no denier of this from its scholars. Know that it does not avail in removing the violation that the grave is inside the mosque within an enclosure (maqsura), as the authors of the treatise claimed, because in any case, it is visible and intended by the common people and those like them among the elite for purposes intended only for Allah Almighty, such as turning towards it and seeking help from it instead of Allah, Blessed and Exalted. The visibility of the grave is the cause of the prohibition, as will be mentioned from Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him. The summary of the speech is that the statement of those we referred to, that the grave of Yahya, peace be upon him, was within the Umayyad Mosque since the Companions and others entered Damascus and no one denied it, is nothing but pure fabrication.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: It becomes clear to us from what we have presented that the noble grave was only introduced into the Prophet's Mosque when there were no Companions left in Medina, and that this was contrary to their purpose when they buried him in his chamber, peace and blessings be upon him. Therefore, it is not permissible for a Muslim, after knowing this truth, to use what happened after the Companions as evidence because it contradicts the authentic hadiths and what the Companions and Imams understood from them, as previously explained. It also contradicts the actions of Umar and Uthman when they expanded the mosque and did not include the grave in it. Therefore, we assert the error of what Al-Walid bin Abdul-Malik did, may Allah forgive him. Even if he was compelled to expand the mosque, he could have expanded it from other directions without touching the noble chamber. Umar bin Al-Khattab pointed out this type of error when he, may Allah be pleased with him, expanded the mosque from other directions and did not touch the chamber, but rather said, "There is no way to it" (70), indicating, may Allah be pleased with him, the prohibition expected from demolishing it and annexing it to the mosque. Despite this clear violation of the aforementioned hadiths and the Sunnah of the Rightly Guided Caliphs, those who violated the command when they introduced the Prophet's grave into the noble mosque took some precautions. They tried to minimize the violation as much as possible. Al-Nawawi said in "Sharh Muslim" (5/14): "When the Companions (71) and the Tabi'in needed to increase the mosque of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, when the Muslims increased in number, and the expansion extended to include the houses of the Mothers of the Believers, including the chamber of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, the burial place of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his two companions Abu Bakr and Umar, may Allah be pleased with them, they built high, circular walls around the grave so that it would not appear in the mosque (72) and the common people would pray towards it, leading to the prohibition. Then they built two walls from the two northern corners of the grave and slanted them until they met, so that no one could face the grave directly." Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab quoted similar to this in "Al-Fath" from Al-Qurtubi, as in "Al-Kawkab" (65/91/1). Ibn Taymiyyah mentioned in "Al-Jawab Al-Bahir" (Folio 9/2): "When the chamber was introduced into the mosque, its door was blocked and another wall was built over it to protect him, peace and blessings be upon him, from his house being taken as a place of celebration (Eid) and his grave as an idol to be worshipped."
