book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: "Prayer in a mosque that contains a grave, like the Prophet's Mosque and the Umayyad Mosque, cannot be said to be prayer in a graveyard, for the grave is within an enclosure separate from the mosque itself, so what prevents praying in it?" This is a statement not issued from knowledge or understanding, because the prohibition regarding the Umayyad Mosque still stands, which is the visibility of the grave from behind the enclosure. Evidence for this is people intending the grave, supplicating at it and by it, seeking help from it instead of Allah, and other things that Allah does not approve of. The Wise Lawgiver only forbade building mosques on graves to block the means and prevent such matters that occur at this grave, as will be explained. So what is the value of this decorated enclosure? It is merely another type of evil that leads people to disobey Allah and His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, and to venerate the occupant of the grave in ways not religiously permissible, which is observed and well-known, and some of which has been alluded to. Is it not sufficient proof of the prohibition that people face the grave during prayer intentionally or unintentionally? Perhaps those referred to and their likes say: "There is no prohibition from this facing either due to the presence of a barrier between the worshippers and the grave, namely the grave's windows and its brass grille." We say: If this barrier were sufficient to prevent [the prohibition], they would not have surrounded the noble Prophet's grave with a high, circular wall, and not being satisfied with that, built two walls to prevent facing the grave, even if it were behind the circular wall. It is authentically reported from Ibn Jurayj that he said: "I said to Ata: Do you dislike praying in the midst of graves? Or in a mosque facing a grave? He said: Yes, that used to be forbidden." Narrated by Abdur-Razzaq in his "Musannaf" (1/404). If this illustrious Tabi'i (Ata bin Abi Rabah) did not consider the mosque wall a barrier between the worshipper and the grave when it is outside the mosque, would windows, grilles, and the grave inside the mosque be considered a barrier?

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Is there in this what convinces those writers of their ignorance, error, and rushing to speak about what they have no knowledge of? Perhaps. As for the Noble Prophet's Mosque, there is no dislike in praying in it, contrary to what they fabricated against us. The detailed discussion on it will come in "Chapter Seven," Allah willing. However, I do not want to miss alerting the noble readers that those writers admit in their previous statement that prayer in a mosque containing a grave not surrounded by an enclosure is a disliked prayer, due to the absence of the reason for which they negated the dislike of prayer in the Umayyad Mosque according to their claim. Can they openly declare this admission to the people? Or is it something they were compelled to say to escape contradicting the previous hadiths publicly, even if they do not call people to act upon it for a purpose not hidden to the intelligent?

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: I said: It is regrettable that this structure has been built over for centuries, if that high green dome has not been removed, and the noble grave has been surrounded by brass windows, decorations, curtains, and other things that the occupant of the grave himself, peace and blessings be upon him, would not approve of. Indeed, when I visited the noble Prophet's Mosque and had the honor of greeting the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in the year 1368 AH, I saw at the bottom of the northern wall of the grave a small mihrab and behind it a platform slightly raised above the floor of the mosque, indicating that this place is designated for prayer behind the grave. I wondered then how this idolatrous phenomenon remained in the era of the State of Monotheism (Tawhid). I say this while acknowledging that I did not see anyone coming to that place to pray due to the strict surveillance by the guards appointed to prevent people from doing anything contrary to Sharia at the noble grave. This is something for which the Saudi state is thanked, but it is not enough nor does it cure. I said three years ago in my book "Ahkam Al-Jana'iz wa Bida'uha" (p. 208 of my original): "The duty is to return the Prophet's Mosque to its previous state by separating it from the Prophet's grave with a wall extending from north to south, so that one entering the mosque does not see in it any violation that would displease its founder, peace and blessings be upon him. I believe this is obligatory upon the Saudi state if it truly wants to be the protector of Monotheism. We have heard that it has ordered the expansion of the mosque again, so perhaps it will adopt this proposal of ours and make the increase from the western side and others, and thereby fill the shortage that will affect the capacity of the mosque if the proposal is implemented. I hope Allah achieves that at its hand, and who is more worthy of that than it?" But the mosque was expanded about two years ago without returning it to what it was in the time of the Companions. And Allah is the Helper. Answer to the Third Doubt: As for the third doubt, which is that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed in the Mosque of Al-Khaif, and it has been mentioned in a hadith that seventy prophets are buried in it, the answer is: We do not doubt his prayer, peace and blessings be upon him, in this mosque, but we say: What was mentioned in the doubt that seventy prophets were buried in it is not proof for two reasons: First: We do not accept the authenticity of the hadith referred to because it was not narrated by anyone concerned with recording authentic hadith, nor was it authenticated by anyone whose authentication is trusted among the early Imams. Nor does hadith criticism support its authentication, for its chain contains narrators who narrate oddities (ghara'ib), which makes the heart not at ease with the authenticity of what they narrated uniquely. Al-Tabarani said in his "Al-Mu'jam Al-Kabir" (3/204/2): Abdan bin Ahmad told us, Isa bin Shadhan told us, Abu Hammam Al-Dallal told us, Ibrahim bin Tahman told us, from Mansur, from Mujahid, from Ibn Umar, raised (marfu') with the wording: "In the Mosque of Al-Khaif is the grave of seventy prophets." Al-Haythami mentioned it in "Al-Majma'" (3/298) with the wording: "Seventy prophets are buried," and said: "Narrated by Al-Bazzar and its men are trustworthy." This is a deficiency in extraction from him, for Al-Tabarani also narrated it as you saw. I said: And the men of Al-Tabarani are also trustworthy except Abdan bin Ahmad, who is Al-Ahwazi as mentioned by Al-Tabarani in "Al-Mu'jam Al-Saghir" (p. 136), and I did not find a biography for him. He is different from Abdan bin Muhammad Al-Marwazi, who is also one of Al-Tabarani's sheikhs in "Al-Saghir" (p. 136) and elsewhere, and he is a trustworthy Hafiz with a biography in "Tarikh Baghdad" (11/135) and "Tadhkirat Al-Huffaz" (2/230) and others. But among the men of this chain are those who narrate oddities, like Isa bin Shadhan; Ibn Hibban said of him in "Al-Thiqat": "He narrates oddities." And Ibrahim bin Tahman; Ibn Ammar Al-Mawsili said of him: "Weak in hadith, confused in hadith." Although this absolute statement is rejected against Ibn Ammar, it indicates that there is something about Ibn Tahman's hadith. This is supported by Ibn Hibban's statement in "Thiqat Atba' Al-Tabi'in" (2/1): "His matter is ambiguous; he has entry among the trustworthy and entry among the weak. He has narrated straight hadiths resembling the hadiths of the reliable, and he has narrated unique things from the trustworthy that are problematic (mu'dalat). We will mention him, Allah willing, in the Book of Separation between Transmitters if Allah, Glory be to Him, decrees that, as well as everything regarding which we paused concerning those who have entry among the trustworthy." Therefore, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said of him in "Al-Taqrib": "Trustworthy, narrates oddities." And Mansur's sheikh, who is Ibn Al-Mu'tamir, is trustworthy, and Ibn Tahman narrated another hadith from him in his Mashyakha (244/2) (73). So the hadith is from his oddities or from the oddities of Ibn Shadhan (74). I fear that the hadith was distorted by one of them, saying: "Qubira" (was buried) instead of "Salla" (prayed), because this second wording is the famous one in the hadith. Al-Tabarani narrated in "Al-Kabir" (3/1551) with a chain whose men are trustworthy from Said bin Jubayr from Ibn Abbas, raised: "Seventy prophets prayed in the Mosque of Al-Khaif..." the hadith. Likewise, Al-Tabarani narrated it in "Al-Awsat" (1/119/2 Zawa'iduhu) (75), and from him Al-Maqdisi in "Al-Mukhtarah" (249/2), Al-Mukhallis in "The Third of the Sixth of Al-Mukhallisiyyat" (70/1), and Abu Muhammad bin Shaiban Al-Adl in "Al-Fawa'id" (2/222/2). Al-Mundhiri said (2/116): "Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Awsat and its chain is good (hasan)." There is no doubt about the goodness of the hadith in my view, for I found another path for it from Ibn Abbas narrated by Al-Azraqi in "Akhbar Makkah" (p. 35) from him as stopped (mawquf) on him, and its chain is suitable for citation as I explained in my large book "Hajjat Al-Wada'" (not yet completed). Then Al-Azraqi narrated it (p. 38) from the path of Muhammad bin Ishaq who said: Someone I do not suspect told me from Abdullah bin Abbas with it as stopped. This is what is known regarding this hadith, and Allah knows best. The summary of the speech is that the hadith is weak; the heart is not at ease with its authenticity. If it is authentic, the answer to it is

Nevertheless, the weakening is applicable against them because they have no verification; rather, they are imitators in everything by their own admission. So it is most likely that they rely on those symbols, and thus the mentioned weakening is proof against them if they are fair" from the following aspect, which is:
Second: The hadith does not say that the graves are visible in the Mosque of Al-Khaif. Al-Azraqi devoted several chapters in the History of Mecca (406-410) to describing the Mosque of Al-Khaif and did not mention that there are prominent graves in it. It is known that the Sharia bases its rulings on the apparent. Since there are no visible graves in the mentioned mosque, there is absolutely no prohibition in praying in it because the graves are obliterated and no one knows them. Indeed, were it not for this report which you knew is weak, it would not have crossed anyone's mind that there are seventy graves in its ground. Therefore, the corruption that usually occurs in mosques built on visible and elevated graves does not occur in it.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: The answer is: No, absolutely not. Here is the clarification from several aspects: First: It has not been proven in a raised (marfu') hadith that Ismail, peace be upon him, or any other noble prophets were buried in the Sacred Mosque. Nothing of that has been reported in any of the relied-upon books of Sunnah, such as the Six Books, Musnad Ahmad, the three Mu'jams of Al-Tabarani, and others, as weak, rather fabricated according to some verifiers (77). The most that has been reported regarding this are problematic (mu'dal) narrations with flimsy, stopped (mawquf) chains extracted by Al-Azraqi in "Akhbar Makkah" (p. 39, 219, and 220). They are not to be paid attention to, even if some innovators presented them as accepted facts (78). Similar to this is what Al-Suyuti cited in "Al-Jami'" from the narration of Al-Hakim in "Al-Kuna" from Aisha, raised, with the wording: "The grave of Ismail is in the Hijr." Second Aspect: The graves allegedly existing in the Sacred Mosque are not visible or prominent. Therefore, they are not intended instead of Allah Almighty, so there is no harm in their presence in the belly of the mosque's earth. Thus, it is not valid to use these narrations as evidence for the permissibility of establishing mosques over graves raised above the surface of the earth, due to the clear difference between the two images. This was the answer of Sheikh Ali Al-Qari, may Allah have mercy on him, in "Mirqat Al-Mafatih" (1/456) after he quoted the saying of the commentator I referred to in the footnote: "Others mentioned that the image of Ismail's grave, peace be upon him, is in the Hijr under the spout, and that in the Hatim between the Black Stone and Zamzam is the grave of seventy prophets." Al-Qari said: "Regarding this, the image of Ismail's grave, peace be upon him, and others is obliterated, so it is not suitable for inference." This is the answer of a deeply knowledgeable scholar and skilled jurist. It contains an indication of what we mentioned earlier, which is that the consideration in this issue is regarding visible graves, and that graves in the belly of the earth do not have a legal ruling attached to them in terms of appearance. Rather, the Sharia is above such a ruling because we know by necessity and observation that the entire earth is a graveyard for the living, as the Exalted said: {Have We not made the earth a container * Of the living and the dead?} [Al-Mursalat: 25-26]. Al-Sha'bi said: "Its belly is for your dead and its back is for your living" (79).

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: I said: And their saying "the doer of which is cursed" refers to the hadith of Ibn Abbas, the weakness of which I explained previously (p. 43), so be aware. Similar to this is the poet's saying: O friend, these are our graves filling the open space So where are the graves from the era of 'Ad? Tread lightly, I do not think the surface of the earth Is anything but these bodies Walk if you can in the air slowly Not arrogantly over the remains of the servants. It is clear and evident that if a grave is not visible and its location is unknown, no corruption results from it, as is observed where you see idolatries and polytheistic practices occurring only at elevated graves, even if they are fake, not at obliterated graves, even if they are real. Wisdom dictates differentiating between the two types, and this is what the Sharia brought as we explained earlier. So it is not permissible to equate them. And Allah is the Helper. Answer to the Fifth Doubt: As for Abu Jandal, may Allah be pleased with him, building a mosque over the grave of Abu Basir, may Allah be pleased with him, during the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, it is a doubt not worth recounting. Were it not that some contemporary people of desires relied on it to reject those confirmed hadiths, I would not have allowed myself to blacken pages to answer it and clarify its invalidity. The discussion on it is from two aspects: First: Rejecting the proof of the alleged building from its foundation because it does not have a chain that stands as evidence. It was not narrated by the authors of the "Sahihs," "Sunan," "Musnads," and others. Rather, Ibn Abd al-Barr cited it in the biography of Abu Basir in "Al-Isti'ab" (4/21-23) as mursal (hurried), saying: "He has a wondrous story in the Maghazi mentioned by Ibn Ishaq and others. Ma'mar narrated it from Ibn Shihab. Abdur-Razzaq mentioned from Ma'mar from Ibn Shihab in the story of the Year of Hudaybiyyah, he said: Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, returned, and Abu Basir, a man from Quraysh who was a Muslim, came to him. Quraysh sent two men seeking him, and they said to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: The covenant you made with us is that you return to us everyone who comes to you as a Muslim. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, handed him over to the two men. They went out until they reached Dhu Al-Hulaifah, where they dismounted to eat some dates they had. Abu Basir said to one of the two men: By Allah, I see this sword of yours is good, O so-and-so. The other drew it and said: Yes, by Allah, it is indeed good; I have tried it and tried it. Abu Basir said to him: Show me, let me look at it. So he enabled him to take it, and he struck him until he grew cold (died). The other fled until he came to Medina and entered the mosque running. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to him when he saw him: This one has seen terror. When he reached the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, he said: By Allah, my companion has been killed and I am killed. Then Abu Basir came and said: O Messenger of Allah, by Allah, Allah has fulfilled your obligation: You returned me to them, then Allah saved me from them. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: Woe to his mother, a kindler of war, if only there were someone with him." When he heard that, he knew that he would return him to them, so he left until he came to the seashore. He said: And Abu Jandal bin Suhayl bin Amr escaped from them and joined Abu Basir... And Musa bin Uqbah mentioned this report about Abu Basir with more complete wordings and fuller context. He said: ... And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, wrote to Abu Jandal and Abu Basir to come to him along with those Muslims with them. The letter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, arrived to Abu Jandal while Abu Basir was dying. So he died with the letter of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in his hand reading it. Abu Jandal buried him in his place, prayed over him, and built a mosque over his grave." I said: You see that this story revolves around Al-Zuhri. It is mursal considering he is a minor Tabi'i who heard from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him; otherwise, it is problematic (mu'dal). Whatever the case, it does not stand as proof. Moreover, the point of evidence in it, which is his saying: "and built a mosque over his grave," does not appear from Ibn Abd al-Barr's context of the story to be from Al-Zuhri's mursal nor from Abdur-Razzaq's narration from Ma'mar from him. Rather, it is from the narration of Musa bin Uqbah as stated by Ibn Abd al-Barr without passing him. Ibn Uqbah did not hear from any of the Companions. So this addition, i.e., his saying "and built a mosque over his grave," is problematic (mu'dal) (80). Indeed, it is denounced (munkar) in my view because the story was narrated by Al-Bukhari in his "Sahih" (5/351-371) and Ahmad in his "Musnad" (4/328-331) as connected (mawsul) from the path of Abdur-Razzaq from Ma'mar who said: Urwa bin Al-Zubair informed me from Al-Miswar bin Makhramah and Marwan with it without this addition. Likewise, Ibn Ishaq cited it in "Al-Sirah" from Al-Zuhri as mursal as in "Mukhtasar Al-Sirah" by Ibn Hisham (3/331-339), and Ahmad connected it (4/323-326) from the path of Ibn Ishaq from Al-Zuhri from Urwa with it like Ma'mar's narration and more complete, and it does not contain this addition. Likewise, Ibn Jarir narrated it in his history (3/271-285) from the path of Ma'mar, Ibn Ishaq, and others from Al-Zuhri with it without this addition. All this indicates that it is a denounced addition due to its problematic nature and the lack of its narration by trustworthy narrators. And Allah grants success. Second Aspect: If that were authentic, it would not be permissible for the explicit hadiths prohibiting building mosques on graves to be rejected by it for two reasons: First: There is nothing in the story indicating that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, knew about that and approved it. Second: Even if we assume that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, knew about that and approved it, it must be interpreted as being before the prohibition, because the hadiths are explicit that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, prohibited that at the end of his life as previously mentioned. It is not permissible to abandon the later text for the sake of the earlier text, assuming its authenticity, in case of conflict. This is clear and not hidden. We ask Allah Almighty to protect us from following desires. Answer to the Sixth Doubt: As for the claim that the prohibition was only for a cause, which is the fear of being tempted by the buried person, and that it has ceased, so the prohibition has ceased, I do not know any scholar who held this doubt except the author of "Ihya' Al-Maqbur." He clung to it and made it his support in rejecting those previous hadiths and the consensus of the Ummah on them. He said (textually) (p. 81, 19): (80) - Do not be deceived, O reader, by what the author of "Ihya' Al-Maqbur" did here. He cited (p. 44) the story we mentioned above from the path of Ibn Abd al-Barr, except that the author deleted from his words "And Musa bin Uqbah mentioned this report" and connected the narration of Abdur-Razzaq from Al-Zuhri with the narration of Musa bin Uqbah so that they became as if they were one narration. It appeared to the onlooker in his context that the story of building the mosque over the grave is from the narration of Abdur-Razzaq from Al-Zuhri, whereas it is from the narration of Musa bin Uqbah without a chain.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Then I found the narration of Musa bin Uqbah in "Tarikh Ibn Asakir" (8/334/1). He narrated it with two chains from him from Ibn Shihab as mursal and mu'dal with the wording: "and made a mosque at his grave." This wording, if authentic, is less contradictory because it is not a text stating that the building was on the grave, but rather at it, and there is a great difference between them. Also, it does not state that Abu Jandal is the one who built the mosque. So reflect.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: "As for the prohibition of building mosques on graves, they agreed on justifying it with two causes: One is that it leads to dirtying the mosque (81)... and the second, which is the saying of the majority, nay all, even those who stated the previous cause, is that this may lead to misguidance and temptation by the grave. Because if it is located in the mosque and is the grave of a Waliy (saint) famous for goodness and righteousness, it is not secure with the passage of time that the belief of the ignorant in him increases, leading them to excessive veneration to the point of intending to pray towards him if he is in the qibla of the mosque, thus leading them to disbelief and polytheism." Then he cited some quotes regarding the mentioned cause from some scholars, including Imam Al-Shafi'i, and his text on that has preceded (p. 43-44). Then the referred author said (p. 20-21): "The mentioned cause has been negated by the firm establishment of faith in the souls of the believers and their upbringing on pure Monotheism and the belief in negating any partner with Allah Almighty and that He, Glory be to Him, is the Unique in creation, existence, and disposal (). With the negation of the cause, the ruling based on it is negated, which is the dislike of establishing mosques and domes on the graves of the Awliya and the righteous." I said: The answer is: It is said: Establish the throne then engrave (Prove the basis first). Prove first that the mentioned fear is the sole cause of the prohibition, then prove that it has been negated. Doing that is harder than stripping thorns. As for the first, there is absolutely no evidence that the cause is the mentioned fear only. Yes, it is possible to say: It is part of the cause. But limiting it to that is invalid because it is also possible to add other rational matters such as imitating the Christians, as preceded in the words of the jurist Al-Haytami and the verifier Al-San'ani, and such as extravagance in spending money on what has no benefit in Sharia, and other things that may appear to the critical researcher. (81) - I said: This cause is invalid for reasons there is no room to explain now. Among the proofs for that specifically regarding the graves of Prophets is that their bodies do not decay as authentically reported from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, so how can the earth be dirtied by them?

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: As for his claim that the cause has been negated by the firm establishment of faith in the souls of the believers etc., it is also an invalid claim. Its explanation is from several aspects: First: The claim is built on a false foundation, which is that believing that Allah is the Unique in creation and existence is sufficient to realize the saving faith with Allah Almighty. It is not so, for this Tawhid, known among scholars as Tawhid Al-Rububiyyah (Lordship), was believed by the polytheists to whom the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was sent, as the Exalted said: {And if you asked them, "Who created the heavens and earth?" they would surely say, "Allah."} (82). Despite that, this Tawhid did not benefit them at all because they disbelieved in Tawhid Al-Uluhiyyah (Worship) and denied it against the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, most vehemently by saying, as Allah recounted about them: {Has he made the gods [only] one God? Indeed, this is a curious thing.} (83). Among the requirements of this Tawhid which they denied is abandoning seeking help from other than Allah, abandoning supplication and slaughtering for other than Allah, and other acts of worship specific to Allah Almighty. So whoever dedicates any of that to other than Allah Almighty has associated partners with Him and made a rival for Him, even if he testifies for Him with Tawhid Al-Rububiyyah. The saving faith is only combining Tawhid Al-Rububiyyah and Tawhid Al-Uluhiyyah and singling out Allah with that. This is detailed elsewhere. If this becomes clear, we know that true faith is not firmly established in the souls of many of those who believe in Tawhid Al-Rububiyyah. I do not want to take the noble reader far in giving examples; it suffices me here to quote what the author we are refuting mentioned. He said after lines of his previous speech (p. 21-22): "We see them (meaning the common people) swearing by the Awliya and uttering regarding them what appears to be blatant disbelief, rather it is disbelief in reality without doubt or suspicion... Many of the ignorant commoners in Morocco utter what is blatant disbelief regarding our master Abdul-Qadir Al-Jilani, may Allah be pleased with him... For we have in Morocco those who say about the Great Pole (Al-Qutb Al-Akbar) our master Abdul-Salam Ibn Mashish, may Allah be pleased with him, that he is the one who created religion and the world. And among them are those who said while rain was falling heavily: O our master Abdul-Salam, be gentle with your servants. This is disbelief."

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: I said: This disbelief is more severe than the disbelief of the polytheists because this contains a declaration of Shirk in Tawhid Al-Rububiyyah as well, which is something we do not know occurred from the polytheists themselves. As for Shirk in Uluhiyyah, it is more frequent among the ignorant of this Ummah, and I do not say their commoners. If this is the state of Muslims today and before today, how can this man say: "And the cause has been negated by the firm establishment of faith in the souls of the believers"? If he means by "the believers" the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, there is no doubt that they were truly believers, knowing the reality of Tawhid which the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, brought to them. But the Islamic Sharia is a general eternal Sharia, so the negation of the cause, even if proven for them, does not necessitate the negation of the ruling for those after them because the cause still exists, and reality is the truest witness to that. Second Aspect: You learned from the previous hadiths that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, warned against taking graves as mosques at the end of his life, indeed during his death illness. So when did the cause he mentioned cease? If it is said: It ceased after his death, peace and blessings be upon him, this is a contradiction of what all Muslims hold, that the best of people is his generation, peace and blessings be upon him. Because saying that implies, based on his previous words, that faith had not yet become firmly established in the souls of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, but became established after his death, peace and blessings be upon him, and that is why the cause did not cease and the ruling remained. This is something I cannot imagine anyone saying due to its clear invalidity. If it is said: It ceased before his death, peace and blessings be upon him, we say: How can that be when he, peace and blessings be upon him, only forbade that in the last breath of his life? This is supported by: Third Aspect: That some of the previous hadiths state the continuation of the ruling until the Hour, like Hadith (12). Fourth Aspect: That the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, only buried him in his chamber, peace and blessings be upon him, fearing that his grave might be taken as a mosque, as previously mentioned from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, in Hadith (4). This fear, either it is said: It was focused on the Companions themselves or on those after them. If the first is said, we say: The fear for those after them is more appropriate. If the second is said, which is the correct view in our opinion, it is definitive proof that the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, did not see the cessation of the cause necessitating the cessation of the ruling, neither in their era nor afterwards. Claiming contrary to their opinion is clear misguidance. This is supported by:

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Fifth Aspect: That the practice of the Salaf continued on this ruling and similar things which necessitate the continuation of the previous cause, which is the fear of falling into Fitnah and misguidance. (85) Since this hadith is clear evidence invalidating what Sheikh Al-Ghumari went to in his aforementioned book, he tried to escape it in two ways: First: Interpreting it to agree with his doctrine. Second: Casting doubt on its establishment. He said (p. 57): "It must be one of two things: either it is not established in itself, or it is carried on other than its apparent meaning necessarily." I said: As for its establishment, there is no doubt about it because it has many paths, some in "Al-Sahih" as preceded. But the people of desires do not adhere to scientific rules in authentication and weakening; rather, whatever is against them, they weaken even if it is authentic in itself like this hadith (86), and whatever is for them, they authenticate or pass even if it is weak in itself. Some other examples of this will follow. And Allah's help is sought. As for its interpretation, he mentioned flimsy reasons, the strongest of which is his saying: "It is a report whose apparent meaning is abandoned by agreement, because the Imams agree on the dislike of leveling the grave and on the recommendation of raising it about a hand span."

Sheikh Ali Al-Qari said in 'Al-Mirqat' (2/372) in explaining the hadith: '(a raised grave) is one that has been built upon until it became high, not the one marked with sand and pebbles or marked () with stones to be known and not stepped on. text: I said: It is strange for someone who claims Ijtihad and forbids Taqlid (blind following) how he diverts hadiths and interprets them to agree with the sayings of the Imams according to his claim, while correct Ijtihad requires the exact opposite. Furthermore, the hadith does not contradict the mentioned agreement because it is specific to the grave built upon; in that case, it is leveled to the ground as preceded from Al-Azhar. The agreement of the Imams is only regarding the origin that should be observed when burying the dead, so it is raised slightly. This is not what the hadith refers to, as Al-Qari, may Allah have mercy on him, stated in what was quoted shortly before in the footnote (p. 73). Then Al-Ghumari quoted in interpreting the hadith from the Shafi'is that they said: He did not mean leveling it to the ground, but rather flattening it, reconciling the hadiths. I said: If this is accepted, it is evidence against Al-Ghumari, not for him, because he does not say it is obligatory to flatten it, but says it is recommended to raise it without limit and recommended to build a dome or mosque over it. Then Al-Ghumari said in the final answer to the hadith: "And the correct view in our opinion is that he meant the graves of the polytheists which they used to sanctify in the Jahiliyyah and in the lands of the disbelievers which the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, conquered, evidenced by the mention of images with them." I said: In some paths of the hadith in Ahmad, Ali's sending of Abu Al-Hayyaj, may Allah be pleased with him, was to some outskirts of Medina when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was in it. This invalidates his claim that the sending was to the lands of the disbelievers. Furthermore, the point of evidence in the hadith is Ali's sending of Abu Al-Hayyaj to level the graves, and he was the chief of police. This contains clear evidence that Ali, and likewise Uthman, may Allah be pleased with them, in the previous report, knew this ruling after his death, peace and blessings be upon him, contrary to what Al-Ghumari claimed.

text: 17 - From Amr bin Shurahbil who said: Do not raise my grave mound, for I saw the Muhajirin disliking that. (107) Know that these reports, although their indications vary, agree on the general prohibition of everything that indicates the veneration of graves in a way that is feared to lead to Fitnah and misguidance, such as building mosques and domes over graves, pitching tents over them, raising them more than the prescribed limit, traveling and frequenting them (108), wiping over them, and such as seeking blessings from the relics of Prophets and the like. All these matters are not legislated according to the Salaf whom we named from the Companions and others. That indicates that they all saw the continuation of the cause of prohibiting building mosques over graves and venerating them with what is not legislated, which is the fear of misguidance and being tempted by the dead, as stated by Imam Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, previously. Evidence for this is their continuation on the ruling based on this cause, for the continuation of one implies the continuation of the other, as is clear. This is regarding those of them who explicitly stated the dislike of building mosques over graves apparently. As for those who explicitly prohibited other than that, such as raising the grave and pitching a tent over it and the like of what we summarized previously, they hold the continuation of the mentioned ruling a fortiori. This is for two reasons: Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Between Noah and Adam were ten centuries, all of them on a Sharia of truth, then they differed, so Allah sent the prophets as bringers of good tidings and warners. (110) Ibn Urwah Al-Hanbali said in {{Al-Kawkab}} (6/212/1): }} This refutes the saying of those among the historians of the People of the Book who claimed that Cain and his sons worshipped fire. {{ I said: And in it is a refutation also of some philosophers and atheists who claim that the origin in humans is polytheism and that monotheism is the emergent thing. This is invalidated and the previous verse supported by two authentic hadiths: from their religion, and I forbade upon them what I made lawful for them, and I commanded them to associate with Me what I did not send down authority for.") (112) Second: His saying, peace and blessings be upon him: }} No child is born but upon Fitra (natural disposition), then his parents make him a Jew or a Christian or a Magian, just as an animal produces a perfect baby animal. Do you perceive in it any mutilation? {{ Abu Huraira said: And read if you wish } The nature of Allah upon which He has created people. No change should there be in the creation of Allah { (113) The verse (114). If this is clear, it is very important for the Muslim to learn how polytheism occurred to the believers after they were monotheists? Many narrations have been reported from a group of the Salaf in interpreting the saying of Allah, Glory be to Him, regarding the people of Noah: } And said, 'Never leave your gods and never leave Wadd or Suwa' or Yaghuth and Ya'uq and Nasr. { (115) That these five, Wadd and those mentioned with him, were righteous servants. When they died, Satan inspired their people to devote themselves at their graves. Then he inspired those who came after them to take idols for them, and beautified that for them claiming it would be more conducive for them to remember them and emulate their righteous deeds. Then he inspired the third generation to worship them instead of Allah Almighty, and deluded them that their fathers used to do that. So Allah sent Noah, peace be upon him, to them commanding them to worship Allah Almighty alone, but they did not respond to him except a few of them. Allah Almighty has recounted his story with them in Surah Nuh. He said: And the first thing worshipped other than Allah on earth was }} Wadd {{ whom they named Wadd {{ (117) and swearing by their owners, for all that leads to exaggeration regarding them and worshipping them instead of Allah Almighty, especially when knowledge is extinguished, ignorance abounds, advisors are few, and devils of Jinn and mankind cooperate to mislead people and take them out of the worship of Allah, Blessed and Exalted. It is not hidden that if it is accepted among us Muslims that part of the wisdom of prohibiting prayer at the three times is blocking the means and avoiding resemblance to the polytheists who worship the sun at those times, then the means in resembling them in building mosques on graves and praying in them is stronger and clearer. Do you not see that until today we have not found any bad effect from some people praying at these prohibited times, while we see the worst effects of praying in these mosques and shrines built on graves, such as wiping over them (119), seeking help from their owners, vowing to them, swearing, and even prostrating to them and other misguidance which is observed and well-known. So the wisdom of the Blessed and Exalted required prohibiting all these matters so that Allah, Blessed and Exalted, is worshipped alone and nothing is associated with Him, thus realizing the command of the Exalted to call upon Him alone in His saying }} And [He revealed] that the masjids are for Allah, so do not invoke with Allah anyone. {{ (120) It is indeed regrettable for every pure-hearted Muslim to find many Muslims falling into violation of the Sharia of the Master of Messengers, peace and blessings be upon him, which came to distance from everything that scratches Tawhid. Then he increases in regret when he sees few or many Sheikhs approving them on that violation claiming that their intentions are good. Allah bears witness that many of them have had their intentions corrupted and polytheism has rusted upon them due to the silence of the likes of these Sheikhs, nay, their justification of all what they see of manifestations of polytheism with that false claim? (121) Where is the good intention, O people, from people who whenever they fall into distress come to a dead person whom they consider righteous, so they call upon him instead of Allah and seek help from him and ask him for well-being and healing and other things that are not asked except from other than Allah and what only Allah is capable of? Rather, if the foot of their animal slips, they call out: O Allah, O Baz. While these Sheikhs may know that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, one day heard some Companions saying to him: What Allah wills and you will. He said: Have you made me a rival to Allah? (122) If this was the denial of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, against those who believed in him, peace and blessings be upon him, fleeing from polytheism, then why do these Sheikhs not deny people saying: O Allah, O Baz, even though it is clearer and more apparent in indicating polytheism than the phrase "What Allah wills and you will"? And why do we see the common people saying without any hesitation: "We relied on Allah and on you" and "We have no one but Allah and you"? That is because these Sheikhs are either like them in misguidance, and one who lacks a thing cannot give it, or they are flattering them, rather cajoling them, so as not to be stigmatized with some stigmas that eliminate their jobs and livelihoods, indifferent to the saying of Allah Almighty } Indeed, those who conceal what We sent down of clear proofs and guidance after We made it clear for the people in the Scripture - those are cursed by Allah and cursed by those who curse { (123) O regret for these Muslims. It was supposed for them to be callers for all people to the religion of Tawhid and a cause for saving them from idolatry and its filth. But due to their ignorance of their religion and following their desires, they became a proverb for idolatry by the polytheists themselves. So they began describing them as being like the Jews in their building of mosques over graves. It came in the book "Da'wat Al-Haqq" by Professor Abdur-Rahman Al-Wakil, may Allah have mercy on him (p. 176-177): As the Jews used to do " The Western disbelievers knew this misguidance into which many Muslims fell, especially the Shia among them, so they exploited it even for the sake of achieving their colonial ambitions. The virtuous Professor Sheikh Ahmad Hasan Al-Baqouri said in a fatwa of his on the prohibition of decorating graves and building domes and mosques over them: And the capable writer and famous historian, the verifier Professor Rafiq Bey Al-Azm said in the conclusion of the biography of Abu Ubaidah, may Allah be pleased with him, from his book "Ashhar Mashahir Al-Islam" (p. 521-524) under the title (A Word on Graves): "We do not intend by this title to research the history of graves like sarcophagi and pyramids and similar landmarks of early idolatry. Rather, we want to pause the reader's thought at the difference of historians regarding the location of Abu Ubaidah's grave, like their difference in determining many of the graves of the illustrious noble Companions who subdued this great kingdom and adorned themselves with those lofty traits and reached a limit of virtue, grace, piety, and righteousness reached by no one from the early and later ones. Historians have elaborated on the news of those great men and took care to record their great deeds in the conquests of kingdoms and countries until they left no need in souls for more. Excellent is what they served the Ummah and the religion with, and the most honorable mention is in the most honorable deeds. For this reason, the graves of the senior Companions and illustrious Mujahideen disappeared from those who came after their generation, except rarely. Then the transmitters of news differed in determining their locations due to the difference of narrators and the conflict of the transcribers' conjectures. If there had been in early Islam a trace of venerating graves and preserving the places of the dead by erecting domes and mosques over them, there would not have been any of this difference, and the graves of those noble Companions would not have been absent from us until now, just as the graves of the imposters and pseudo-sheikhs, which the innovators of Muslims invented after the first eras, have not been absent. They opposed the action of the Companions and Tabi'in until most of these domes came to represent the temples of the ancients and bring back the biography of idolatry in its ugliest types and furthest tendencies from the truth and closest to polytheism. If Muslims had taken a lesson afterwards from the disappearance of the graves of the Companions from whom they took this religion and by whom Allah granted victory to Islam, they would not have dared to erect domes over graves and venerate the dead, which reason and Sharia refuse. They opposed in all this the Companions and Tabi'in who delivered to us the trust of their Prophet, so we wasted it, and the secrets of the Sharia, so we toyed with them. Here is what Muslim narrated in his "Sahih" regarding graves from Abu Al-Hayyaj Al-Asadi who said: Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: Shall I not send you on the same mission as the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent me? That you do not leave an image without obliterating it, nor a raised grave without leveling it. And in his "Sahih" also from Thumamah bin Shufayy who said: We were with Fadalah bin Ubaid in the land of the Romans at "Rodos". A companion of ours died, so Fadalah ordered his grave and it was leveled. Then he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, ordering their leveling (127). Thus, those who delivered to us the trust of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, conveyed to us. Then, confirming the covenant of trust, they started with everything the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, commanded them with themselves so that we may follow their Sunnah and be guided by the guidance of their Prophet. But our minds fell short of grasping the meaning of those particulars, and our perceptions declined from the station of knowledge of the wisdom of divine legislation and the Prophetic command decreeing not to erect graves. Gradation in the steps of idolatry governed us, so we did not heed that wisdom, and we judged with our deficient [minds] against the Sharia, so we judged the permissibility of erecting graves as a recommendation for such particulars until they became universals and a breach in religion and a corruption of the doctrine of Tawhid. For we kept graduating until we made mosques over them and sought their remains with vows and offerings, and we fell thereby into what the Lawgiver commanded us to obliterate graves for (128). All this while we are still in heedlessness of the wisdom of legislation, colliding with the truth and it collides with us until we perish with those who perish." I said: Some people, especially those of modern culture among them, may think that polytheism has vanished and there is no return for it due to the spread of sciences and the enlightenment of minds by them. This is a false thought, for reality contradicts it, since it is observed that polytheism in its various types and manifestations is still striking its pegs in most parts of the earth, especially in the lands of the West, the heartland of disbelief and worship of prophets, saints, idols, matter, great men, and heroes. Among the most prominent manifestations of that to the eye is the spread of statues among them. It is regrettable that this phenomenon has begun to spread slowly in some Islamic countries without any denial from Muslim scholars. Why do we take the readers far? Here are many Muslim countries, especially the Shia among them, containing numerous manifestations of polytheism and idolatry such as prostrating to graves, circumambulating them, facing them in prayer and prostration, calling upon them instead of Allah Almighty, and other things mentioned previously. Even if we assume that the earth has been purified from the filth of polytheism and idolatry of various types, it is not permissible for us to permit taking means that are feared to lead to polytheism, because we are not secure that these means will lead some Muslims to polytheism. Rather, we are certain that polytheism will occur in this Ummah at the end of time if it has not occurred now. Here are some texts reported regarding that from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so that you may be clear about the matter:

text: Indeed, if the reader pauses with his thought at this matter contemplatively, he will soon be taken by wonder at the first instance at the loss of the graves of those great men and the disappearance of their locations from the view of the transmitters of news and recorders of artifacts, despite the greatness of their owners' status and their fame that covered the horizons and filled souls with reverence for their worth and acknowledgment of the virtue of their precedence to faith and spreading the call of the Quran. Undoubtedly, the least the reader's self would suggest upon contemplating this matter is: That those men's graves should be known by specification, and high domes with pillars should be erected over them, if not for their fame for righteousness, piety, true faith, and companionship of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, then for what they performed of great deeds that the greatest of men are incapable of. So how did their graves disappear from the view of historians, and their tombs containing the senior Companions and Tabi'in become obliterated, until the biographers differed in determining their locations, and traces were wiped out on most of them except what they knew later by conjecture and guessing, and showed its trace by building on it after that time? While what is observed among Muslims is directing care to the graves of the dead to the utmost by being meticulous in raising and constructing them, erecting domes over them, and taking mosques near them, especially the graves of unjust rulers who had no praiseworthy trace in Islam, and the pseudo-sheikhs and imposters, most of whom were ignorant of the rulings of faith. There is no comparison between them and those great men like Abu Ubaidah bin Al-Jarrah and his brothers from the senior noble Companions who transmitted the religion fresh and tender and reached a far place in piety and virtue? The answer to this is that the Companions and Tabi'in were not, in their era, less appreciative of the worth of men and venerating the status of those who excelled among them of famous heroes and the best of the Ummah. However, they used to disdain constructing graves of the dead and venerating remains, due to their realization of the explicit prohibition of that from the Owner of the bright, tolerant Hanifiyyah Sharia which came to eradicate the root of idolatry and wipe out traces of venerating remains or devotion to the graves of the dead. They see that the best of generations are the obliterated ones (126) (126) - I said: This is not a hadith. The Sunnah is raising the grave above the ground about a hand span. book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: Dislike of Praying in Mosques Built over Graves After we have finished answering the previous doubts, and it has become clear from them to the noble reader that the prohibition of building mosques over graves is a confirmed ruling established until the Day of Judgment, and we have finished explaining the wisdom of the prohibition, it is appropriate for us to move to another issue which is a requisite of the mentioned ruling, namely the ruling on praying in these mosques built over graves. We mentioned previously (p. 30) that the prohibition of building mosques over graves implies the prohibition of praying in them, based on the principle that prohibiting the means implies prohibiting the end a fortiori. It results from this that praying in these mosques is forbidden, and the prohibition in such a place implies invalidity as is known among scholars (137). Imam Ahmad and others held the view of the invalidity of prayer in them. But we see that the issue needs detailing, so I say: Second: That praying in them is a means to venerating the one buried in them with a veneration outside the limit of Sharia, so it is forbidden as a precaution and to block the means, especially since the evils of mosques built over graves are visible to the eye as mentioned repeatedly. Scholars have stated both causes. The scholar Ibn Al-Malak from the Hanafi scholars said: Taking mosques over them was forbidden because praying in them is imitating the Sunnah of the Jews. Al-Qari quoted it in "Al-Mirqat" (1 / 470) and approved it. Some late Hanafi scholars and others said likewise as will come. Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Al-Qa'idah Al-Jalilah" (p. 22): Taking a place as a mosque means taking it for the five prayers and others as mosques are built for that. A place taken as a mosque is intended for the worship of Allah and supplicating to Him, not supplicating to creatures. So he, peace be upon him, forbade taking their graves as mosques intended for prayers in them as mosques are intended, even if the one intending that intends only the worship of Allah alone [because that is a means to intending the mosque for the sake of the grave's occupant and supplicating to him and supplicating at his place]. So the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, forbade... so many of them permitted it at these times, which is the more apparent of the two sayings of scholars. Because if the prohibition is for blocking the means, it is permitted for a preponderant interest. Performing prayers with specific causes is needed at these times, and if not done in them, its interest is missed, so they were permitted due to the interest in them, unlike what has no cause for it can be done at another time, so no preponderant interest is missed by prohibiting it, and it contains harm necessitating its prohibition. If his prohibition of prayer at these times was to block the means to Shirk lest it leads to prostrating to the sun and supplicating to it and asking it as the people of calling upon the sun, moon, and stars do, who call upon them and ask them, it was known that calling upon the sun and prostrating to it is forbidden in itself and greater in prohibition than the prayer which he forbade lest it leads to calling upon the stars. Likewise, when he forbade taking the graves of prophets and righteous people as mosques, and forbade intending them for prayer at them lest that leads to calling upon them, calling upon them and prostrating was greater in prohibition than taking their graves as mosques. Know that the dislike of prayer in these mosques is a matter agreed upon by scholars as previously explained (p. 44) and will come. They only differed regarding its invalidity. The apparent Madhhab of the Hanbalis is that it is not valid, and the verifier Ibn al-Qayyim asserted this as preceded (p. 41-43). Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Iqtida' Al-Sirat Al-Mustaqim Mukhalafat Ashab Al-Jahim" (p. 159): Al-Ayni Al-Hanafi mentioned similar in (Umdat Al-Qari) (4 / 149). And in (Al-Kawkab Al-Durri 'ala Jami' Al-Tirmidhi) by the investigating Sheikh Muhammad Yahya Al-Kandahlawi Al-Hanafi, the text is (p. 153): (As for taking mosques over them, it is due to the resemblance to the Jews and their taking mosques over the graves of their prophets and elders, and due to the veneration of the dead and remote resemblance to idol worshippers if the grave is in the direction of the Qibla. The dislike of it being in the direction of the Qibla is greater than the dislike of it being on the right or left. If it is behind the worshipper, it is lighter than all that but is not free from dislike."

The Previous Ruling Includes All Mosques Except the Prophet's Mosque

Then know that the previous ruling includes all mosques, the large and the small, the old and the new, due to the generality of the evidences (142). No mosque containing a grave is excepted from this except the Noble Prophet's Mosque, because it has a special virtue not found in any other mosque over graves (143). This is due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "A prayer in this mosque of mine is better than a thousand prayers elsewhere, except the Sacred Mosque (Al-Masjid Al-Haram), [for it is better]" (144). And due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) also: "What is between my house (145) and my pulpit is a garden from the gardens of Paradise" (146), and other virtues. If one were to say that prayer in it is disliked (Makruh), that would mean equating it with other mosques and removing these virtues from it, and this is not permissible as is apparent. We derived this meaning from the previous words of Ibn Taymiyyah (p. 127-128) regarding the reason for the permissibility of prayers with specific causes (Dhat al-Asbab) during the prohibited times. Just as prayer was permitted during these times because prohibiting it would lead to wasting it such that its virtue could not be retrieved due to the passing of its time, likewise it is said regarding prayer in his Mosque (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Then I found that Ibn Taymiyyah explicitly stated this, saying in his book "Al-Jawab Al-Bahir fi Zuwwar Al-Maqabir" (147) (p. 22 / 12):

What adds to its weakness is what Al-Bukhari narrated in "Al-Maghazi" of his "Sahih" from Saeed bin Al-Musayyib from his father (who said): "I saw the tree, then I came to it later and did not recognize it." And via Tariq bin Abdul Rahman who said: I set out for Hajj and passed by people praying. I said: "What is this mosque?" They said: "This is the tree where the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) took the Pledge of Satisfaction (Bay'at al-Ridwan)." So I came to Saeed bin Al-Musayyib and he laughed and said: "My father told me that he was among those who pledged allegiance to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) under the tree. When we went out the next year, we forgot it and could not find it." In a narration: "It became obscured to us." Saeed said: "The Companions of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not know it, but you know it? Then you are more knowledgeable!" I say: Even if we lost this interrupted narration as a witness in our research after confirming its weakness, we have gained what is stronger than it, which is suitable as evidence for our topic: the hadith of Al-Musayyib and the hadith of Ibn Umar. Al-Hafiz said in his explanation of it: "The wisdom in that is so that no temptation (Fitnah) occurs with it due to the good that happened under it. If it had remained, there would be no safety from some ignorant people venerating it, until the matter might lead them to believe it has the power to benefit or harm, as we see observed now regarding what is less than it." Ibn Umar pointed to this by saying: "It was a mercy from Allah," meaning its concealment from them after that was a mercy from Allah the Exalted. I say: Among those trees referred to by Al-Hafiz was a tree I saw more than ten years ago east of the Martyrs of Uhud cemetery, outside its wall. It had many rags on it. Then I saw it in the season of last year (1371 AH) having been uprooted from its roots, praise be to Allah. May Allah protect the Muslims from the evil of other trees and Taghuts (idols/false gods) worshipped besides Allah the Exalted.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
First: That building mosques over graves is a greater crime than raising graves and pitching tents over them because of the curse reported regarding building, unlike raising and pitching mentioned.
Second: That it is assumed of those Salaf to have understanding and knowledge. If a prohibition is established from one of them regarding something that is less than what the Lawgiver forbade, and this prohibition [of the greater thing] was not narrated from one of them, we are certain that he forbids it as well. Even if we assume the prohibition did not reach him, his prohibition of what is less than this necessitates prohibition of it [the greater] a fortiori, as is not hidden. Thus, it is proven that the claim of the negation of the mentioned cause, and everything built upon it, is false due to its contradiction of the method of the righteous Salaf (may Allah be pleased with them) and its collision with the authentic hadiths. And Allah is the One sought for help.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
[Intending to Pray in Mosques Built over Graves Invalidates the Prayer]
The worshipper in the mentioned mosques has two states:
First: That he intends to pray in them for the sake of the graves and seeking blessing from them, as many of the common people and not a few of the elite do.
Second: That he prays in them coincidentally, not intending the grave.
In the first state, there is no doubt about the prohibition of prayer therein, rather its invalidity. Because if he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) forbade building mosques over graves and cursed the one who does that, then the prohibition of intending to pray in them is more deserving, and the prohibition here implies invalidity (Batil), as previously mentioned recently.
[Dislike of Prayer in the Mentioned Mosques Even if Not Intended for the Sake of the Grave]

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
As for the second state, the ruling of the invalidity of prayer therein does not appear clear to me, but rather only Dislike (Karahah). This is because the verdict of invalidity in this case requires specific evidence. The evidence by which we established invalidity in the previous case was valid based on the prohibition of building a mosque over a grave. So it is valid to say that intending to pray in this [is prohibited], but only with the realization of the intent of building. Thus, it is valid to say the prayer in it is invalid [if intended]. Without intent, there is no specific prohibition one can rely on regarding it, nor can it be analogized to it with a correct analogy, let alone a fortiori. Perhaps this is the reason the majority went for Dislike rather than Invalidity. I say this acknowledging that the subject requires further investigation and that the saying of invalidity is probable. Whoever has knowledge regarding any of that, let him kindly explain it with evidence, thanked and rewarded. As for the saying of the Dislike of prayer in mosques built over graves, this is the least a researcher can say, for two reasons:
First: That praying in them involves resembling the Jews and Christians who used to, and still do, intend worship in those mosques built over graves (138).
(138) - I read an article in "Al-Mukhtar" magazine, May 1958 issue, under the title "The Vatican: The Ancient Holy City," in which its writer "Ronald Carlos Petit" describes St. Peter's Church in this city, saying (p. 40):

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: "St. Peter's Church is the largest church of its kind in the Christian world. It stands on a square dedicated to Christian worship for more than seventeen centuries. It stands over the grave of the Saint himself, the fisherman, the disciple of Christ. Under its floors lies a maze of ancient tombs and old Roman ruins." Then he mentioned that about one hundred thousand people visit it during major holidays for worship.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
(peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) [prohibited] taking this place for the worship of Allah alone lest it be taken as a means to Shirk with Allah. An action, if it leads to corruption and has no preponderant benefit, is forbidden, just as prayer is forbidden during the three times because of the preponderant corruption in it, which is resembling the polytheists, which leads to Shirk. Intending to pray during those times has no preponderant benefit because voluntary prayer is possible in other times. For this reason, scholars disputed regarding [prayers with] specific causes (139).
(139) - Meaning prayers with specific causes, like the two rak'ahs of greeting the mosque, the Sunnah of ablution, and similar ones.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: "So these mosques built over the graves of prophets, righteous people, kings, and others must be removed by demolition or otherwise. This is something I know of no disagreement about among the known scholars. Prayer in them is disliked without any disagreement I know of, and it is not valid according to us in the apparent view of the Madhhab (school of thought), due to the prohibition and curse reported regarding that, and due to other hadiths. There is no difference in this issue whether the buried person is one; our companions only differed regarding a cemetery devoid of a mosque: is its limit three graves, or is prayer forbidden near a single grave even if there is no other grave near it? There are two views." I say: The second view is the one he preferred in "Al-Ikhtiyarat Al-Ilmiyyah," where he said (p. 25): "There is no such distinction in the speech of Ahmad and the generality of his companions. Rather, the generality of their speech, reasoning, and deduction necessitates preventing prayer near one of the graves, and this is the correct view. A 'Maqbarah' (cemetery) is wherever someone is buried, not that it is a collection of graves. Our companions said: And whatever enters into the name of the cemetery from what is around the graves, prayer is not performed in it. This designates that the prevention covers the prohibited area (Haram) of the single grave and the courtyard added to it. Al-Amidi and others mentioned that prayer is not permissible in it (i.e., the mosque whose Qiblah is towards the grave) until there is another barrier between the wall and the cemetery. Some of them mentioned that it is explicitly stated by Ahmad." Abu Bakr Al-Athram said: I heard Abu Abdullah, meaning Ahmad, being asked about prayer in the cemetery? He disliked prayer in the cemetery. It was said to him: 'If the mosque is between the graves, is prayer performed in it?' He disliked that the obligatory prayer be performed in it, but permitted funeral prayers in it. Imam Ahmad also said: 'Prayer is not performed in a mosque between graves except funerals, because this is the Sunnah for funerals.' Al-Hafiz Ibn Rajab said in 'Al-Fath': He refers to the action of the Companions. Ibn Al-Mundhir said: Nafi', the freed slave of Ibn Umar, said: We prayed over Aisha and Umm Salamah, and the Imam that day was Abu Hurairah, and Ibn Umar attended that. See 'Al-Kawakib Al-Darari' (65 / 81 / 1 and 2)."

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
Perhaps Imam Ahmad's restriction in the first narration to mentioning the Obligatory prayer only does not indicate that other Sunnah prayers are permissible. For it is known that performing voluntary prayers in houses is better, and for that reason, he did not mention them with the Obligatory prayer. This is supported by the generality of his saying in the second narration: "Prayer is not performed in a mosque between graves except funerals." This is an explicit text regarding what we said. It is supported by what is explicitly narrated from Ahmad regarding Anas: He used to dislike that a mosque be built over graves. It is explicit that the wall of the mosque does not suffice as a barrier between it and the grave. Rather, perhaps this saying negates the permissibility of building a mosque between graves absolutely, and this is closer [to the truth] because it cuts off the material of Shirk. Then Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said in "Al-Iqtida": "The structure over the grave of Ibrahim (peace be upon him) was closed; no one entered it until around the fourth century. It was said that some women connected to the Caliphs saw a dream regarding that, so they opened it. It was said: When the Christians took over these areas, they opened that. Then it was left as a mosque after the later conquests. The people of virtue among our Sheikhs used not to pray in the entirety of that structure, and they forbade their companions from praying in it, following the command of the Messenger (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and fearing disobedience to him, as mentioned previously. This was how their Sheikhs were in the past. As for our Sheikhs today, they are in heedlessness of this Sharia ruling. Many of them intend to pray in such mosques. I used to go with some of them when I was young, not yet learned in the Sunnah, to the grave of Sheikh Ibn Arabi to pray with him near it. When I learned the prohibition of that, I debated the referenced Sheikh a lot regarding it until Allah guided him, and he refrained from praying there. He used to admit that to me and thank me for being a cause for his guidance. May Allah have mercy on him and forgive him. Praise be to Allah who guided us to this, and we would not have been guided had Allah not guided us."
[Dislike of Prayer in the Mosque Built over the Grave even without facing it]

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
Know that the dislike of prayer in mosques built over graves is consistent in every case, whether the grave is in front of him, behind him, to his right, or to his left. Prayer therein is disliked in every case. However, the dislike intensifies if the prayer is towards the grave, because in this case, the worshipper commits two violations: the first is praying in these mosques, and the other is praying towards the grave, which is forbidden absolutely, whether in a mosque or other than a mosque, by the authentic text from the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as previously mentioned (p. 24). Rulings of scholars on that: Al-Bukhari pointed to this meaning by his saying in "Al-Sahih": "Chapter: What is disliked regarding taking mosques over graves. And when Al-Hasan bin Al-Hussein bin Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) died, his wife pitched a dome over his grave for a year, then it was removed. They heard a shouter saying: 'Have they found what they lost?' Another answered him: 'Nay, they despaired, so they turned back.'" Then he cited some of the previously mentioned hadiths. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar Al-Shafi'i said in his explanation: "The suitability of this trace to the chapter is that the one residing in the tent (Fustat) is not free from praying there, so it necessitates taking a mosque near the grave. The grave might be in the direction of the Qiblah, so the dislike increases (140)."
(140) - Sheikh Muhammad bin Mukhaimar, one of the scholars of Al-Azhar, quoted in "Al-Qawl Al-Mubin" (p. 81) from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar that he said in "Sharh Al-Fath" regarding the hadith of Dhu al-Khalasah from "Sahih Al-Bukhari" in the discussion on battles, the text of which is: "In the hadith is the prohibition of praying in mosques that contain graves by which people are tempted, and that it is obligatory to remove them." I say: I did not see it in the mentioned place of "Al-Fath", so it is possible it is in another place in it. And Allah knows best.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
And in "Shir'at al-Islam" from the books of the Hanafis, the text is (p. 569): "It is disliked to build a mosque over a grave to pray in." This, in its absolute sense, supports what we mentioned of the scholars' opinions. Similar was mentioned previously from Imam Muhammad (may Allah have mercy on him) (p. 58). In these quotes is support for what we went towards regarding the dislike of prayer in mosques built over graves absolutely, whether he prays towards it or not. One must distinguish between this issue and prayer towards a grave that does not have a mosque over it. In this image, the dislike is realized only when facing the grave. Although some scholars did not stipulate facing it in this image either, and said it is prevented to pray around the grave absolutely, as mentioned recently from the Hanbalis. Similar is in "Hashiyat al-Tahtawi" on "Maraqi al-Falah" from the Hanafi books (p. 208). This is what befits the chapter of Blocking the Means (Sadd al-Dhara'i), due to his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "...So whoever avoids doubtful matters has cleared himself in regard to his religion and his honor, and whoever falls into doubtful matters falls into the Haram, like the shepherd who grazes around a sanctuary, all but grazing therein..." the Hadith (141).
(141) - Agreed upon from the hadith of Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, and it is extracted in "Takhrij al-Halal" (20).

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: From "Al-Majmu'ah Al-Muniriyyah": "In this is an explicit declaration of the prohibition of building over graves. It applies to one who builds on the sides of the grave's pit, as many people do by raising the graves of the dead a cubit or more. Because it is not possible to make the grave itself a mosque. That indicates that the meaning is some of what is near it which connects to it. It applies to one who builds near the sides of the grave as well, as in domes, mosques, and large shrines, in a way that the grave is in their middle or in a side of them. For this is 'building over the grave' as is not hidden to anyone with the slightest understanding. Just as it is said: 'The Sultan built' even though the thickness of the building only directly touched the sides of the city, village, or place. There is no difference whether those sides upon which the building was placed are close to the center, as in a small city, small village, and narrow place, or far from the center, as in a city, large village, and wide place. Whoever claims that there is something in the Arabic language that prevents this usage does not know the language of the Arabs, does not understand their tongue, and does not know what is used in their speech."

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text: I say: This chain is weak. Abu Ziyad Al-Sha'bani is unknown (Majhul). It appears he is Khiyar bin Salamah Abu Ziyad Al-Shami, and his peer is Abu Umayyah Al-Sha'bani (he is Yuhmad with a Damma on the Ya, Sukun on the Muhmala [Ha], and Kasra on the Mim). Both are acceptable (Maqbul) as in "Al-Taqrib". However, the narrator from them, Habib the Muezzin, is unknown. Ibn Asakir mentioned him in his "Tarikh" and did not add to his biography more than saying about him: "He used to call the Adhan in the Suq al-Ahad mosque." The narrator from him, Ahmad bin Anas, I did not find a biography for him. What invalidates this trace from Sufyan is that he is one of the narrators of the hadith of Abu Hurairah coming later that prayer in his mosque (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is equal to a thousand prayers. It is unlikely that he would say something contrary to what is authentic according to him from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Also invalidating it is that the most authentic report from him (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) regarding the virtue of prayer in Bayt al-Maqdis is that it is equal to a thousand prayers. Narrated by Ibn Majah (1 / 429-430) and Ahmad (6 / 463) with a good (Jayyid) chain. This trace says: It is equal to forty thousand prayers. Then it appeared to me that its chain is not good; it has a defect that impugns its authenticity, even if I had a predecessor in authenticating it. I clarified it in "Da'if Abi Dawood", "Chapter on Lamps in Mosques." Yes, it is authentically reported that prayer in Bayt al-Maqdis is a quarter of the prayer in the Prophet's Mosque. Narrated by Al-Bayhaqi. In this invalidates the trace of Al-Thawri a fortiori, as is not hidden.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
"This is the established correct [wording]. However, some of them narrated it by meaning and said (my grave). But he (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), when he said this statement, had not yet been buried (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). For this reason, none of the Companions used this as proof when they disputed regarding the place of his burial. If this were with them, it would have been a text regarding the point of dispute. But he was buried in the 'Room of Aisha' in the place where he died. May my father and mother be ransomed for him, blessings of Allah and His peace be upon him."
(Note) Among the illusions of scholars is that Al-Nawawi in "Al-Majmu'" attributed the hadith to the two Sheikhs (Bukhari and Muslim) with the wording "my grave," and it has no basis in their books. This required notification.

book_title: Warning the Worshipper against taking Graves as Mosques
text:
"And prayer in mosques built over graves is forbidden absolutely, unlike his mosque (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), for prayer in it is equal to a thousand prayers. It was founded on piety. Its sanctity existed during his life (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the lives of his Rightly Guided Caliphs before the Room was entered into it. It was only entered after the extinction of the era of the Companions." Then he said (67 / 169 / 2): "The mosque was virtuous before the Room entered it. The virtue of the mosque was because the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) built it for himself and for the believers to pray to Allah—he and the believers—until the Day of Resurrection. So its construction by him is a virtue. How so, when he said: 'A prayer in this mosque of mine is better than a thousand prayers elsewhere except the Sacred Mosque' (148). And he said: 'Do not set out on a journey except to three mosques: The Sacred Mosque, Al-Aqsa Mosque, and this mosque of mine' (149). This virtue is established for it before the Room entered it. It is not permissible to think that it became better than it was by the Room entering it. They did not intend to enter the Room into it; rather, they intended to expand it by including the rooms of the wives of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), so the Room entered it by necessity, with the dislike of those among the Salaf who disliked that." (150) Then he said (5512): "Whoever believes that before the grave it had no virtue—while the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) used to pray in it along with the Emigrants and Helpers—and that virtue only occurred for it during the Caliphate of Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik when he introduced the Room into his mosque: such a person says this only if he is an ignoramus excessive in ignorance, or a disbeliever. He is denying what he (the Prophet) brought, deserving of death. The Companions used to supplicate in his mosque just as they used to supplicate during his life; no Sharia occurred for them other than the Sharia he taught them during his life... Rather, he forbade them from taking his grave as a place of celebration ('Eid) or the grave of anyone else as a mosque to pray in to Allah the Mighty and Majestic, to block the means to Shirk. So may Allah send blessings upon him and his family and grant them peace, and reward him with the best He rewarded a prophet on behalf of his nation. For he conveyed the message, fulfilled the trust, advised the nation, strove for Allah as He deserves to be striven for, and worshipped Allah until certainty (death) came to him from his Lord."
(148) - Agreed upon from the hadith of Abu Hurairah. I extracted it in "Al-Irwa'" (1 / 971).
(149) - Agreed upon from the hadith of Abu Hurairah as well. It is extracted in my book "Ahkam al-Jana'iz wa Bida'uha" (Rules of Funerals and their Innovations) (p. 224-225).
(150) - See what was mentioned previously (at the beginning of the book regarding examples of the Salaf's dislike for that).
